**Skopje** ([/ˈskɒpjeɪ/](/wiki/Help:IPA/English "Help:IPA/English") [*SKOP-yay*](/wiki/Help:Pronunciation_respelling_key "Help:Pronunciation respelling key"),^[\[5\]](#cite_note-5)^^[\[6\]](#cite_note-6)^ [US](/wiki/American_English "American English") also [/ˈskoʊpjeɪ/](/wiki/Help:IPA/English "Help:IPA/English") [*SKOHP-yay*](/wiki/Help:Pronunciation_respelling_key "Help:Pronunciation respelling key");^[\[7\]](#cite_note-7)^ [Macedonian](/wiki/Macedonian_language "Macedonian language"): Скопје [\[ˈskɔpjɛ\]](/wiki/Help:IPA/Macedonian "Help:IPA/Macedonian") [](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/transcoded/2/20/Mk-Skopje.ogg/Mk-Skopje.ogg.mp3 "Play audio")^[ⓘ](/wiki/File:Mk-Skopje.ogg "File:Mk-Skopje.ogg")^; [Albanian](/wiki/Albanian_language "Albanian language"): *Shkup* , [Albanian](/wiki/Albanian_language "Albanian language") [definite form](/wiki/Definiteness "Definiteness"): *Shkupi* ) is the capital and [largest city](/wiki/List_of_cities_in_North_Macedonia_by_population "List of cities in North Macedonia by population") of [North Macedonia](/wiki/North_Macedonia "North Macedonia"). It is the country's political, cultural, economic, and academic centre. Skopje lies in the [Skopje Basin](/wiki/Skopje_Basin "Skopje Basin").{#ooui-php-1}

[Scupi](/wiki/Scupi "Scupi") is attested for the first time in the second century AD as a city in [Roman Dardania](/wiki/Roman_Dardania "Roman Dardania").^[\[8\]](#cite_note-8)^^[\[9\]](#cite_note-9)^ When the [Roman Empire](/wiki/Roman_Empire "Roman Empire") was divided into eastern and western halves in AD 395, Scupi came under [Byzantine](/wiki/Byzantine "Byzantine") rule from [Constantinople](/wiki/Constantinople "Constantinople"). During much of the [early medieval period](/wiki/Early_medieval_period "Early medieval period"), the town was contested between the Byzantines and the [Bulgarian Empire](/wiki/First_Bulgarian_Empire "First Bulgarian Empire"), whose capital it was between 972 and 992. In 1004, when it was again seized by the Byzantine Empire, the city became a centre of a new [province](/wiki/Theme_(Byzantine_district) "Theme (Byzantine district)") called [Bulgaria](/wiki/Theme_of_Bulgaria "Theme of Bulgaria"). From 1282, the town was part of the [Serbian Empire](/wiki/Serbian_Empire "Serbian Empire"), of which it was the capital from 1346 to 1371.{#cite_ref-9}

In 1392, Skopje was conquered by the [Ottoman Empire](/wiki/Ottoman_Empire "Ottoman Empire"), who called it *Üsküb* (اسکوب).^[\[a\]](#cite_note-10)^ The town stayed under Ottoman control for over 500 years, serving as the capital of the [pashasanjak](/wiki/Sanjak "Sanjak") of *Üsküp* and later the [Vilayet of Kosovo](/wiki/Vilayet_of_Kosovo "Vilayet of Kosovo"). Its central position in the [Ottoman Balkans](/wiki/Ottoman_Balkans "Ottoman Balkans") made it a significant centre of commerce and administration during the Ottoman era. In 1912, it was annexed by the [Kingdom of Serbia](/wiki/Kingdom_of_Serbia "Kingdom of Serbia") during the [Balkan Wars](/wiki/Balkan_Wars "Balkan Wars").^[\[10\]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTERamet2006[httpsbooksgooglecombooksidFTw3lEqi2-oCdqserbiaannexed1912pgPA40_40]-11)^{#cite_ref-FOOTNOTERamet2006[httpsbooksgooglecombooksidFTw3lEqi2-oCdqserbiaannexed1912pgPA40_40]_11-0}

During [World War I](/wiki/World_War_I "World War I") the city was seized by the [Kingdom of Bulgaria](/wiki/Kingdom_of_Bulgaria "Kingdom of Bulgaria"), and, after the war, it became part of the newly formed [Kingdom of Yugoslavia](/wiki/Kingdom_of_Yugoslavia "Kingdom of Yugoslavia") as the capital of [Vardarska Banovina](/wiki/Vardarska_Banovina "Vardarska Banovina"). In [World War II](/wiki/World_War_II "World War II"), the city was again captured by Bulgaria and in 1945 became the capital of [SR Macedonia](/wiki/SR_Macedonia "SR Macedonia"), a [federated state](/wiki/Federated_state "Federated state") within [Yugoslavia](/wiki/Democratic_Federal_Yugoslavia "Democratic Federal Yugoslavia").^[\[11\]](#cite_note-12)^ The city developed rapidly, but this was interrupted in 1963 when it was hit by [a disastrous earthquake](/wiki/1963_Skopje_earthquake "1963 Skopje earthquake").{#cite_ref-12}

Skopje is located on the upper course of the [Vardar](/wiki/Vardar "Vardar") River and on a major north--south [Balkan](/wiki/Balkans "Balkans") route between [Belgrade](/wiki/Belgrade "Belgrade") and [Athens](/wiki/Athens "Athens"). It is a centre for the chemical, timber, textile, leather, printing, and metal-processing industries. Industrial development of the city has been accompanied by development of the trade, logistics, and banking sectors, as well as an emphasis on the fields of transportation, culture and sport. According to the last official census from 2021, Skopje had a population of 526,502 inhabitants.^[\[2\]](#cite_note-stats2-2)^{#cite_ref-stats2_2-1}  

Name {#Name}
------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Skopje&action=edit&section=1 "Edit section: Name")\]  
See also: [Other names of Skopje](/wiki/Names_of_European_cities_in_different_languages:_Q-T#S "Names of European cities in different languages: Q-T")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a7/Skoplje_1912.jpg/220px-Skoplje_1912.jpg)](/wiki/File:Skoplje_1912.jpg) Serbian troops overseeing the city's renaming from "Üsküb" to "Skoplje" following Serbia's annexation of [Vardar Macedonia](/wiki/Vardar_Macedonia "Vardar Macedonia") in 1912

The city is attested for the first name in *[Geography](/wiki/Geography_(Ptolemy) "Geography (Ptolemy)")* by [Ptolemy](/wiki/Ptolemy "Ptolemy")  AD 150 as one of the cities of [Roman Dardania](/wiki/Roman_Dardania "Roman Dardania"). Ptolemy describes the city in Latin as *Scupi* and ancient Greek as *Σκοῦποι*. The [toponym](/wiki/Toponym "Toponym") likely belongs to a group of similar [Illyrian](/wiki/Illyrian_language "Illyrian language") toponyms which have been transmitted to Slavic languages in the same way as the modern [Macedonian](/wiki/Macedonian_language "Macedonian language") toponym *Skopje* : *Skoplje* and *Uskoplje* in Bosnia, *Uskoplje* in Dalmatia (Croatia).^[\[12\]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDuridanov197518–19-13)^{#cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDuridanov197518–19_13-0}

**Shkup** , the name of the city in [Albanian](/wiki/Albanian_language "Albanian language"), developed directly from Roman-era **Scupi** in agreement with the Albanian phonological development, the basis of evidence of an earlier Albanian settlement in the area.^[\[13\]](#cite_note-14)^^[\[14\]](#cite_note-15)^^[\[15\]](#cite_note-16)^^[\[16\]](#cite_note-17)^ **Shkupi** is the definite form of **Shkup** in Albanian.^[\[17\]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHeroldLangerLechler201029-18)^ *Skopje* , the name of the city during the Middle Ages, is the local Slavic (Macedonian) rendition of *Scupi* .^[\[18\]](#cite_note-history-19)^ The [Ottoman Turkish](/wiki/Ottoman_Turkish "Ottoman Turkish") rendition of the city's name is *Üsküb* ([Ottoman Turkish](/wiki/Ottoman_Turkish_language "Ottoman Turkish language"): اسكوب) and it was adapted in Western languages in "Uskub" or "Uskup", and these two appellations were used in the [Western world](/wiki/Western_world "Western world") until 1912. Some Western sources also cite "Scopia" and "Skopia".^[\[19\]](#cite_note-britannica-20)^ *Scopia* is the name of the city in [Aromanian](/wiki/Aromanian_language "Aromanian language").^[\[20\]](#cite_note-21)^{#cite_ref-21}

When [Vardar Macedonia](/wiki/Vardar_Macedonia "Vardar Macedonia") was annexed by the [Kingdom of Serbia](/wiki/Kingdom_of_Serbia "Kingdom of Serbia") in 1912, the city officially became *Skoplje* ([Serbian Cyrillic](/wiki/Serbian_Cyrillic_alphabet "Serbian Cyrillic alphabet"): Скопље) and many languages adopted this name. To reflect local pronunciation, the city's name was eventually spelled as *Skopje* ([Macedonian](/wiki/Macedonian_language "Macedonian language"): Скопје) after the [Second World War](/wiki/Second_World_War "Second World War"), when standard [Macedonian](/wiki/Macedonian_language "Macedonian language") became the official language of the new [Socialist Republic of Macedonia](/wiki/Socialist_Republic_of_Macedonia "Socialist Republic of Macedonia").  

Geography {#Geography}
----------------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Skopje&action=edit&section=2 "Edit section: Geography")\]  

### Topography {#Topography}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Skopje&action=edit&section=3 "Edit section: Topography")\]

Skopje is in the north of the country, in the centre of the [Balkan peninsula](/wiki/Balkan_peninsula "Balkan peninsula"), and approximately halfway between [Belgrade](/wiki/Belgrade "Belgrade") and [Athens](/wiki/Athens "Athens"). The city was built in the [Skopje Valley](/wiki/Skopje_Valley "Skopje Valley"), oriented on a west--east axis, along the course of the [Vardar](/wiki/Vardar "Vardar") river, which flows into the [Aegean Sea](/wiki/Aegean_Sea "Aegean Sea") in Greece. The valley is approximately 20 km (12 mi) wide^[\[21\]](#cite_note-tourism-22)^ and it is limited by several mountain ranges to the north and south. These ranges limit the urban expansion of Skopje, which spreads along the Vardar and the [Serava](/w/index.php?title=Serava&action=edit&redlink=1 "Serava (page does not exist)") \[[mk](https://mk.wikipedia.org/wiki/%D0%A1%D0%B5%D1%80%D0%B0%D0%B2%D0%B0 "mk:Серава"); [sr](https://sr.wikipedia.org/wiki/%D0%A1%D0%B5%D1%80%D0%B0%D0%B2%D0%B0 "sr:Серава")\], a small river which comes from the north. In its administrative boundaries, the City of Skopje stretches for more than 33 km (21 mi),^[\[22\]](#cite_note-transports-23)^ but it is only 10 km (6.2 mi) wide.^[\[23\]](#cite_note-figures-24)^{#cite_ref-figures_24-0}

Skopje is approximately 245 m above sea level and covers 571.46 km^2^.^[\[24\]](#cite_note-drisla-25)^ The urbanised area only covers 337 km^2^, with a density of 65 inhabitants per hectare.^[\[25\]](#cite_note-nature-26)^ Skopje, in its administrative limits, encompasses many villages and other settlements, including [Dračevo](/wiki/Dra%C4%8Devo,_Skopje "Dračevo, Skopje"), [Gorno Nerezi](/wiki/Gorno_Nerezi "Gorno Nerezi") and Bardovci. According to the 2021 census, the City of Skopje had 526,502 inhabitants.^[\[2\]](#cite_note-stats2-2)^^[\[26\]](#cite_note-meta-27)^{#cite_ref-meta_27-0}

The City of Skopje reaches the [Kosovo](/wiki/Kosovo "Kosovo") border to the north-east. Clockwise, it is also bordered by the municipalities of [Čučer-Sandevo](/wiki/%C4%8Cu%C4%8Der-Sandevo_Municipality "Čučer-Sandevo Municipality"), [Lipkovo](/wiki/Lipkovo_Municipality "Lipkovo Municipality"), [Aračinovo](/wiki/Ara%C4%8Dinovo_Municipality "Aračinovo Municipality"), [Ilinden](/wiki/Ilinden_Municipality "Ilinden Municipality"), [Studeničani](/wiki/Studeni%C4%8Dani_Municipality "Studeničani Municipality"), [Sopište](/wiki/Sopi%C5%A1te_Municipality "Sopište Municipality"), [Želino](/wiki/%C5%BDelino_Municipality "Želino Municipality") and [Jegunovce](/wiki/Jegunovce_Municipality "Jegunovce Municipality").

### Hydrography {#Hydrography}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Skopje&action=edit&section=4 "Edit section: Hydrography")\]

The [Vardar](/wiki/Vardar "Vardar") river, which flows through Skopje, is at approximately 60 km (37 mi) from its source near [Gostivar](/wiki/Gostivar "Gostivar"). In Skopje, its average discharge is 51 m^3^/s, with a wide amplitude depending on seasons, between 99.6 m^3^/s in May and 18.7 m^3^/s in July. The water temperature is between 4.6 °C in January and 18.1 °C in July.^[\[27\]](#cite_note-vardar-28)^{#cite_ref-vardar_28-0}

Several rivers meet the Vardar within the city boundaries. The largest is the [Treska](/wiki/Treska "Treska"), which is 130 km (81 mi) long. It crosses the [Matka Canyon](/wiki/Matka_Canyon "Matka Canyon") before reaching the Vardar on the western extremity of the City of Skopje. The [Lepenac](/wiki/Lepenac "Lepenac"), coming from [Kosovo](/wiki/Kosovo "Kosovo"), flows into the Vardar on the north-western end of the urban area. The Serava, also coming from the north, had flowed through the [Old Bazaar](/wiki/Old_Bazaar,_Skopje "Old Bazaar, Skopje") until the 1960s when it was diverted towards the west because its waters were very polluted. Originally, it met the Vardar close to the seat of the [Macedonian Academy of Sciences and Arts](/wiki/Macedonian_Academy_of_Sciences_and_Arts "Macedonian Academy of Sciences and Arts"). Nowadays, it flows into the Vardar near the ruins of [Scupi](/wiki/Scupi "Scupi").^[\[28\]](#cite_note-29)^ [Markova Reka](/wiki/Markova_Reka "Markova Reka"), which originates in Mount [Vodno](/wiki/Vodno "Vodno"), meets the Vardar at the eastern extremity of the city. These three rivers are less than 70 km (43 mi) long.^[\[23\]](#cite_note-figures-24)^{#cite_ref-figures_24-1}

The City of Skopje incorporates two artificial lakes, on the Treska. [Lake Matka](/wiki/Lake_Matka "Lake Matka") is the result of the construction of a dam in [Matka Canyon](/wiki/Matka_Canyon "Matka Canyon") in the 1930s, and the Treska lake was dug for leisurely purposes in 1978.^[\[23\]](#cite_note-figures-24)^ Three small natural lakes can be found near [Smilkovci](/wiki/Smilkovci "Smilkovci"), on the north-eastern edge of the urban area.{#cite_ref-figures_24-2}

The river Vardar historically caused many floods, such as in 1962, when its outflow reached 1110 m^3^/s^−1^.^[\[27\]](#cite_note-vardar-28)^ Several works have been carried out since Byzantine times to limit the risks, and since the construction of the [Kozjak dam](/wiki/Kozjak_Hydro_Power_Plant "Kozjak Hydro Power Plant") on the Treska in 1994, the flood risk is close to zero.^[\[29\]](#cite_note-kozjak-30)^{#cite_ref-kozjak_30-0}

The subsoil contains a large [water table](/wiki/Water_table "Water table") which is alimented by the Vardar and functions as an underground river. Under the table lies an [aquifer](/wiki/Aquifer "Aquifer") contained in [marl](/wiki/Marl "Marl"). The water table is 4 to 12 m under the ground and 4 to 144 m deep. Several wells collect its waters but most of the drinking water used in Skopje comes from a [karstic](/wiki/Karstic "Karstic") spring in [Rašče](/wiki/Ra%C5%A1%C4%8De "Rašče"), west of the city.^[\[25\]](#cite_note-nature-26)^{#cite_ref-nature_26-1}

### Geology {#Geology}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Skopje&action=edit&section=5 "Edit section: Geology")\]

The Skopje valley is bordered on the west by the [Šar Mountains](/wiki/%C5%A0ar_Mountains "Šar Mountains"), on the South by the [Jakupica](/wiki/Jakupica "Jakupica") range, on the east by hills belonging to the [Osogovo](/wiki/Osogovo "Osogovo") range, and on the north by the [Skopska Crna Gora](/wiki/Skopska_Crna_Gora "Skopska Crna Gora"). Mount [Vodno](/wiki/Vodno "Vodno"), the highest point inside the city limits, is 1066 m high and is part of the [Jakupica](/wiki/Jakupica "Jakupica") range.^[\[23\]](#cite_note-figures-24)^{#cite_ref-figures_24-3}

Although Skopje is built on the foot of Mount Vodno, the urban area is mostly flat. It comprises several minor hills, generally covered with woods and parks, such as Gazi Baba hill (325 m), Zajčev Rid (327 m), the foothills of Mount Vodno (the smallest are between 350 and 400 m high) and the promontory on which [Skopje Fortress](/wiki/Skopje_Fortress "Skopje Fortress") is built.^[\[30\]](#cite_note-31)^{#cite_ref-31}

The Skopje valley is near a seismic fault between the African and Eurasian [tectonic plates](/wiki/Tectonic_plate "Tectonic plate") and experiences regular seismic activity.^[\[31\]](#cite_note-damages-32)^ This activity in enhanced by the porous structure of the subsoil.^[\[32\]](#cite_note-33)^ Large earthquakes occurred in Skopje in 518, 1555 and 1963.^[\[31\]](#cite_note-damages-32)^{#cite_ref-damages_32-1}

The Skopje valley belongs to the Vardar geotectonic region, the subsoil of which is formed of [Neogene](/wiki/Neogene "Neogene") and [Quaternary](/wiki/Quaternary "Quaternary") deposits. The substratum is made of [Pliocene](/wiki/Pliocene "Pliocene") deposits including [sandstone](/wiki/Sandstone "Sandstone"), [marl](/wiki/Marl "Marl"), and various conglomerates. It is covered by a first layer of Quaternary sands and silt, which is between 70 and 90 m deep. The layer is topped by a much smaller layer of clay, sand, silt, and gravel, carried by the [Vardar](/wiki/Vardar "Vardar") river. It is between 1.5 and 5.2 m deep.^[\[33\]](#cite_note-ohis-34)^{#cite_ref-ohis_34-0}

In some areas, the subsoil is [karstic](/wiki/Karst "Karst"). It led to the formation of canyons, such as the [Matka Canyon](/wiki/Matka_Canyon "Matka Canyon"), which is surrounded by ten caves. They are between 20 and 176 m deep.^[\[34\]](#cite_note-macedonia.co.uk-35)^{#cite_ref-macedonia.co.uk_35-0}

### Climate {#Climate}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Skopje&action=edit&section=6 "Edit section: Climate")\]

Skopje has a [humid subtropical climate](/wiki/Humid_subtropical_climate "Humid subtropical climate") ([Köppen](/wiki/K%C3%B6ppen_climate_classification "Köppen climate classification"): *Cfa* ), bordering on a [humid continental climate](/wiki/Humid_continental_climate "Humid continental climate") ([Köppen](/wiki/K%C3%B6ppen_climate_classification "Köppen climate classification"): *Dfa* )^[\[35\]](#cite_note-36)^^[\[36\]](#cite_note-37)^ with a mean annual temperature of 12.6 °C (55 °F). Precipitation is relatively low due to the pronounced [rain shadow](/wiki/Rain_shadow "Rain shadow") of the [Accursed Mountains](/wiki/Accursed_Mountains "Accursed Mountains") to the north-west, being significantly less than what is received on the Adriatic Sea coast at the same latitude. The summers are long, hot and relatively dry with low [humidity](/wiki/Humidity "Humidity"). Skopje's average July high is 32 °C (90 °F). On average Skopje experiences 88 days above 30 °C (86 °F) each year, and 10.2 days above 35.0 °C (95 °F) every year.{#cite_ref-37}

Winters are short, relatively cold and wet. Snowfalls are common in the winter period, but heavy snow accumulation is rare and the snowcover lasts only for a few hours or a few days if heavy. In summer, temperatures are usually above 31 °C (88 °F) and sometimes above 40 °C (104 °F). In spring and autumn, the temperatures range from 15 to 24 °C (59 to 75 °F). In winter, the day temperatures are roughly in the range from 5--10 °C (41--50 °F), but at nights they often fall below 0 °C (32 °F) and sometimes below −10 °C (14 °F). Typically, temperatures throughout one year range from −13 °C to 39 °C. Occurrences of precipitation are evenly distributed throughout the year, being heaviest from October to December, and from April to June.

### Environment {#Environment}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Skopje&action=edit&section=7 "Edit section: Environment")\]

The City of Skopje encompasses various natural environments, having diverse [fauna](/wiki/Fauna "Fauna") and [flora](/wiki/Flora "Flora"). However, it is threatened by the intensification of agriculture and urban extension. The largest protected area within the city limits is Mount Vodno, which is a popular leisure destination. A cable car connects its peak to the downtown, and many pedestrian paths run through its woods. Other large natural spots include the [Matka Canyon](/wiki/Matka_Canyon "Matka Canyon").^[\[25\]](#cite_note-nature-26)^{#cite_ref-nature_26-2}

The city itself comprises several parks and gardens amounting to 4,361 hectares. Amongst these are the [City Park](/w/index.php?title=City_Park_(Skopje)&action=edit&redlink=1 "City Park (Skopje) (page does not exist)") \[[mk](https://mk.wikipedia.org/wiki/%D0%93%D1%80%D0%B0%D0%B4%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%B8_%D0%BF%D0%B0%D1%80%D0%BA_(%D0%A1%D0%BA%D0%BE%D0%BF%D1%98%D0%B5) "mk:Градски парк (Скопје)")\], built by the Ottoman Turks at the beginning of the 20th century; Žena Borec Park, in front of the Parliament; the university arboretum; and Gazi Baba forest. Many streets and boulevards are planted with trees.^[\[40\]](#cite_note-41)^{#cite_ref-41}

Steel processing---a crucial activity for the local economy---is responsible for [soil pollution](/wiki/Soil_pollution "Soil pollution") with heavy metals such as [lead](/wiki/Lead "Lead"), [zinc](/wiki/Zinc "Zinc") and [cadmium](/wiki/Cadmium "Cadmium"), and [air pollution](/wiki/Air_pollution "Air pollution") with [nitrogen oxide](/wiki/Nitrogen_oxide "Nitrogen oxide") and [carbon monoxide](/wiki/Carbon_monoxide "Carbon monoxide").^[\[25\]](#cite_note-nature-26)^ Vehicle traffic and [district heating](/wiki/District_heating "District heating") plants are also responsible for air pollution.{#cite_ref-nature_26-3}

Water treatment plants are being built, but much of the polluted water is still being discharged untreated into the [Vardar](/wiki/Vardar "Vardar").^[\[25\]](#cite_note-nature-26)^ Waste is disposed of in the open-air municipal landfill site, 15 km (9.3 mi) north of the city. Every day, it receives 1,500 m^3^ of domestic waste and 400 m^3^ of industrial waste. Health levels are better in Skopje than in the rest of North Macedonia, and no link has been found between the low environmental quality and the health of the residents.^[\[41\]](#cite_note-security-42)^{#cite_ref-security_42-0}

Urbanism {#Urbanism}
--------------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Skopje&action=edit&section=8 "Edit section: Urbanism")\]  

### Urban morphology {#Urban_morphology}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Skopje&action=edit&section=9 "Edit section: Urban morphology")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4c/GUP_Skopje_2002_mal.jpg/220px-GUP_Skopje_2002_mal.jpg)](/wiki/File:GUP_Skopje_2002_mal.jpg) Skopje urban plan for 2002--2020:  
City centre  
Collective housing  
Individual housing  
Industrial areas

The urban morphology of Skopje was deeply impacted by the [1963 earthquake](/wiki/1963_Skopje_earthquake "1963 Skopje earthquake"), which destroyed 80% of the city, and by its subsequent reconstruction.^[\[31\]](#cite_note-damages-32)^ For instance, neighbourhoods were rebuilt in such a way that the demographic density remains low to limit the impact of potential future earthquakes.^[\[42\]](#cite_note-post-43)^{#cite_ref-post_43-0}

Reconstruction following the 1963 earthquake was mainly conducted by the Polish architect [Adolf Ciborowski](/wiki/Adolf_Ciborowski "Adolf Ciborowski"), who had already planned the reconstruction of [Warsaw](/wiki/Warsaw "Warsaw") after [World War II](/wiki/World_War_II "World War II"). Ciborowski divided the city into blocks dedicated to specific activities. The banks of the [Vardar](/wiki/Vardar "Vardar") river became natural areas and parks, areas between the main boulevards were built with [high-rise](/wiki/High-rise "High-rise") housing and shopping centres, and the suburbs were left to individual housing and industry.^[\[43\]](#cite_note-reconstruction-44)^ Reconstruction had to be quick to relocate families and to relaunch the local economy. To stimulate economic development, the number of thoroughfares was increased and future urban extension was anticipated.^[\[44\]](#cite_note-45)^{#cite_ref-45}
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f1/Skopje_SPOT_1114.jpg/220px-Skopje_SPOT_1114.jpg)](/wiki/File:Skopje_SPOT_1114.jpg) Skopje as seen by the [SPOT satellite](/wiki/SPOT_(satellite) "SPOT (satellite)"). Mount Vodno is visible on the bottom left of the picture.

The south bank of the Vardar river generally comprises high-rise tower blocks, including the vast Karpoš neighbourhood which was built in the 1970s west of the centre. Towards the east, the new municipality of [Aerodrom](/wiki/Aerodrom_Municipality_(Skopje) "Aerodrom Municipality (Skopje)") was planned in the 1980s to house 80,000 inhabitants on the site of the old airport. Between Karpoš and Aerodrom lies the city centre, rebuilt according to plans by Japanese architect [Kenzo Tange](/wiki/Kenzo_Tange "Kenzo Tange"). The centre is surrounded by a row of long buildings suggesting a wall (*Gradski Zid*).^[\[42\]](#cite_note-post-43)^{#cite_ref-post_43-1}

On the north bank, where the most ancient parts of the city lie, the [Old Bazaar](/wiki/Old_Bazaar,_Skopje "Old Bazaar, Skopje") was restored and its surroundings were rebuilt with low-rise buildings, so as not to spoil views of the [Skopje Fortress](/wiki/Skopje_Fortress "Skopje Fortress"). Several institutions, including the university and the [Macedonian Academy of Sciences and Arts](/wiki/Macedonian_Academy_of_Sciences_and_Arts "Macedonian Academy of Sciences and Arts"), were also relocated to the north bank to reduce borders between the ethnic communities. The north bank is mostly inhabited by Muslim Albanians, Turks, and Roma, whereas Christian ethnic Macedonians predominantly reside on the south bank.^[\[43\]](#cite_note-reconstruction-44)^{#cite_ref-reconstruction_44-1}

The earthquake left the city with few historical monuments, apart from the Ottoman-era [Old Bazaar](/wiki/Old_Bazaar,_Skopje "Old Bazaar, Skopje"), and the reconstruction, conducted between the 1960s and 1980s, turned Skopje into a [modernist](/wiki/Modernist_architecture "Modernist architecture") city. At the end of the 2000s, the city centre experienced profound changes. A highly controversial^[\[45\]](#cite_note-46)^ urban project, [Skopje 2014](/wiki/Skopje_2014 "Skopje 2014"), was adopted by the municipal authorities to give the city a more monumental and historical aspect, and thus to transform it into a proper national capital. Several [neoclassical](/wiki/Neoclassical_architecture "Neoclassical architecture") buildings destroyed in the 1963 earthquake were rebuilt, including the national theatre, and streets and squares were refurbished. Many other elements were also built, including fountains, statues, hotels, government buildings and bridges. The project has been criticised because of its cost and its historicist aesthetics.^[\[46\]](#cite_note-objections-47)^ The large Albanian minority felt it was not represented in the new monuments,^[\[47\]](#cite_note-Albanian_objections-48)^ and launched side projects, including a new square over the boulevard that separates the city centre from the [Old Bazaar](/wiki/Old_Bazaar,_Skopje "Old Bazaar, Skopje").^[\[48\]](#cite_note-49)^{#cite_ref-49}

### Urban sociology {#Urban_sociology}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Skopje&action=edit&section=10 "Edit section: Urban sociology")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a9/Kapistec.jpg/220px-Kapistec.jpg)](/wiki/File:Kapistec.jpg) Kapištec neighbourhood, developed during the 1970s. Some post-earthquake prefabricated houses can be seen in the foreground.

Skopje is an ethnically diverse city, and its urban sociology primarily depends on ethnic and religious affiliation. [Macedonians](/wiki/Macedonians_(ethnic_group) "Macedonians (ethnic group)") form 66% of the city population, whilst [Albanians](/wiki/Albanians_in_North_Macedonia "Albanians in North Macedonia") and [Roma](/wiki/Roma_in_North_Macedonia "Roma in North Macedonia") account respectively for 20% and 6%.^[\[49\]](#cite_note-stats1-50)^ Each ethnic group generally [self-segregates](/wiki/Self-segregates "Self-segregates") itself to certain areas of the city. Macedonians live south of the [Vardar](/wiki/Vardar "Vardar") in areas massively rebuilt after 1963, whilst Muslims live on the northern side, in the oldest neighbourhoods of the city. These neighbourhoods are considered more traditional, whereas the south side evokes modernity to Macedonians.^[\[50\]](#cite_note-thiesen57-51)^{#cite_ref-thiesen57_51-0}

The northern areas are the poorest; this is especially true for [Topaana](/wiki/Topaana "Topaana"), in [Čair municipality](/wiki/%C4%8Cair_municipality "Čair municipality"), and for [Šuto Orizari municipality](/wiki/%C5%A0uto_Orizari_municipality "Šuto Orizari municipality"), which are the two main Roma neighbourhoods. They are made of many illegal constructions not connected to the electric grid nor water supply, which are passed from one generation to another. Topaana, close to the [Old Bazaar](/wiki/Old_Bazaar,_Skopje "Old Bazaar, Skopje"), is a very old area: it was first mentioned as a Roma neighbourhood in the beginning of the 14th century. It has between 3,000 and 5,000 inhabitants. Šuto Orizari, on the northern edge of the city, is a municipality of its own, with [Romani](/wiki/Romani_language "Romani language") as its local official language. It was developed after the 1963 earthquake to accommodate Roma who had lost their homes.^[\[51\]](#cite_note-roma-52)^{#cite_ref-roma_52-0}

The population density varies greatly from one area to another. So does the size of the living area per person. The city average was at 19.41 m^2^ (208.93 sq ft) per person as of 2002^[\[update\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Skopje&action=edit)^, but at 24 m^2^ (258 sq ft) in [Centar](/wiki/Centar_municipality_(Skopje) "Centar municipality (Skopje)") on the south bank, and only 14 m^2^ (151 sq ft) in [Čair](/wiki/%C4%8Cair_municipality "Čair municipality") on the north bank. In [Šuto Orizari](/wiki/%C5%A0uto_Orizari_municipality "Šuto Orizari municipality"), the average was at 13 m^2^ (140 sq ft).^[\[49\]](#cite_note-stats1-50)^{#cite_ref-stats1_50-1}  

### Localities and villages {#Localities_and_villages}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Skopje&action=edit&section=11 "Edit section: Localities and villages")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/be/Gorno_Nerezi_2013_%281%29.JPG/220px-Gorno_Nerezi_2013_%281%29.JPG)](/wiki/File:Gorno_Nerezi_2013_(1).JPG) [Gorno Nerezi](/wiki/Gorno_Nerezi "Gorno Nerezi"), a village on the northern side of Mount Vodno

Outside of the urban area, the City of Skopje encompasses many small settlements. Some of them are becoming outer suburbs, such as [Čento](/wiki/%C4%8Cento "Čento"), on the road to Belgrade, which has more than 23,000 inhabitants, and [Dračevo](/wiki/Dra%C4%8Devo,_Skopje "Dračevo, Skopje"), which has almost 20,000 inhabitants.^[\[52\]](#cite_note-dwelling-53)^ Other large settlements are north of the city, such as [Radišani](/wiki/Radi%C5%A1ani "Radišani"), with 9,000 inhabitants,^[\[52\]](#cite_note-dwelling-53)^ whereas smaller villages can be found on Mount Vodno or in [Saraj municipality](/wiki/Saraj_municipality "Saraj municipality"), which is the most rural of the ten municipalities that form the City of Skopje.^[\[53\]](#cite_note-region-54)^{#cite_ref-region_54-0}

Some localities outside the city limits are also becoming outer suburbs, particularly in [Ilinden](/wiki/Ilinden_municipality "Ilinden municipality") and [Petrovec municipality](/wiki/Petrovec_municipality "Petrovec municipality"). They benefit from the presence of major roads, railways, and the airport, [Skopje International](/wiki/Skopje_International "Skopje International"), in [Petrovec](/wiki/Petrovec,_North_Macedonia "Petrovec, North Macedonia").^[\[53\]](#cite_note-region-54)^{#cite_ref-region_54-1}  

### Pollution {#Pollution}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Skopje&action=edit&section=12 "Edit section: Pollution")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6c/Urban_pollution_%2C%D0%93%D1%80%D0%B0%D0%B4%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%BE_%D0%B7%D0%B0%D0%B3%D0%B0%D0%B4%D1%83%D0%B2%D0%B0%D1%9A%D0%B5.jpg/220px-Urban_pollution_%2C%D0%93%D1%80%D0%B0%D0%B4%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%BE_%D0%B7%D0%B0%D0%B3%D0%B0%D0%B4%D1%83%D0%B2%D0%B0%D1%9A%D0%B5.jpg)](/wiki/File:Urban_pollution_,%D0%93%D1%80%D0%B0%D0%B4%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%BE_%D0%B7%D0%B0%D0%B3%D0%B0%D0%B4%D1%83%D0%B2%D0%B0%D1%9A%D0%B5.jpg) Pollution contributors in the area of Skopje

Air pollution is a serious problem in Skopje, especially in winter.^[\[54\]](#cite_note-aljazeera-55)^ Concentrations of certain types of [particulate matter](/wiki/Particulates "Particulates") (PM2 and PM10) are regularly over twelve times the [WHO](/wiki/World_Health_Organization "World Health Organization")-recommended maximum levels. In winter, smoke regularly obscures vision and can lead to problems for motorists. Together with [Kosovo](/wiki/Kosovo "Kosovo") and [Bosnia and Herzegovina](/wiki/Bosnia_and_Herzegovina "Bosnia and Herzegovina"), [North Macedonia](/wiki/North_Macedonia "North Macedonia") has the most polluted urban areas in Europe.^[\[55\]](#cite_note-56)^{#cite_ref-56}

Skopje's high levels of pollution are caused by a combination of smoke from houses, emissions from the industry, public and private transport, and a general lack of interest in caring for the environment. Central heating is often not affordable, and so households often burn [firewood](/wiki/Firewood "Firewood"), as well as used car tyres, plastic waste, petroleum, and other possibly flammable waste, which emits toxic chemicals harmful to the population, especially to children and the elderly.^[\[54\]](#cite_note-aljazeera-55)^{#cite_ref-aljazeera_55-1}

The city's smog has reduced its air quality and affected the health of many of its citizens, many of whom have died from pollution-related illnesses.

An [application](/wiki/Application_software "Application software") called *AirCare* ([Macedonian](/wiki/Macedonian_language "Macedonian language"): МојВоздух, [romanized](/wiki/Romanization_of_Macedonian "Romanization of Macedonian"): *MojVozduh*) has been launched by local eco-activist [Gorjan Jovanovski](/wiki/Gorjan_Jovanovski "Gorjan Jovanovski") to help citizens track pollution levels. It uses a [traffic light](/wiki/Traffic_light "Traffic light") system, with purple for heavily polluted air, red for high levels detected, [amber](/wiki/Amber_(colour) "Amber (colour)") for moderate levels detected, and green for when the air is safe to inhale.^[\[56\]](#cite_note-57)^ The application relies on both government and volunteer [sensors](/wiki/Sensor "Sensor") to track hourly air pollution. Unfortunately, government sensors are frequently inoperable and malfunctioning, causing the need for more low-cost, but less accurate, volunteer sensors to be put up by citizens. Faults on government sensors are especially frequent when the pollution is measured is extremely high, according to the AQILHC (Air Quality Index Levels of Health Concern).^[\[57\]](#cite_note-58)^{#cite_ref-58}

Skopje topped the ranks in December 2017 as one of the most polluted cities in the world.^[\[58\]](#cite_note-59)^ In 2017, as part of the city's efforts to reduce pollution, a [CityTree](/wiki/CityTrees "CityTrees") was installed, and promoted by German ambassador [Christine Althauser](/w/index.php?title=Christine_Althauser&action=edit&redlink=1 "Christine Althauser (page does not exist)") \[[de](https://de.wikipedia.org/wiki/Christine_Althauser "de:Christine Althauser")\].^[\[59\]](#cite_note-60)^{#cite_ref-60}

On 29 November 2019, a march, organised by the Skopje Smog Alarm activist community,^[\[60\]](#cite_note-skopje-smog-61)^ attracted thousands of people who opposed the government's lack of action in dealing with the city's pollution, which has worsened since 2017, contributing to around 1300 deaths annually.^[\[61\]](#cite_note-62)^^[\[60\]](#cite_note-skopje-smog-61)^{#cite_ref-skopje-smog_61-1}

### Origins {#Origins}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Skopje&action=edit&section=14 "Edit section: Origins")\]

The rocky promontory on which [Skopje Fortress](/wiki/Skopje_Fortress "Skopje Fortress") stands was the first site to be settled in Skopje. The earliest vestiges of human inhabitance found on this site date from the [Chalcolithic](/wiki/Chalcolithic "Chalcolithic") ([4th millennium BC](/wiki/4th_millennium_BC "4th millennium BC")).^[\[62\]](#cite_note-kalepre-65)^{#cite_ref-kalepre_65-0}

Although the Chalcolithic settlement must have been of some significance, it declined during the [Bronze Age](/wiki/Bronze_Age "Bronze Age"). Archeological research suggests that the settlement always belonged to the same culture, which progressively evolved due to contacts with [Balkan](/wiki/Balkan "Balkan") and [Danube](/wiki/Danube "Danube") cultures, and later with the [Aegean](/wiki/Aegean_culture "Aegean culture"). The locality eventually disappeared during the [Iron Age](/wiki/Iron_Age "Iron Age")^[\[63\]](#cite_note-kaleant-66)^ when [Scupi](/wiki/Scupi "Scupi") emerged on Zajčev Rid hill, some 5 km (3.1 mi) west of the fortress promontory. At the centre of the Balkan peninsula and on the road between the Danube and [Aegean Sea](/wiki/Aegean_Sea "Aegean Sea"),^[\[64\]](#cite_note-provincial-67)^ it was a prosperous locality, although its history is not well known.^[\[64\]](#cite_note-provincial-67)^{#cite_ref-provincial_67-1}

During the Iron Age, the area of Skopje was inhabited by the [Dardani](/wiki/Dardani "Dardani"). [Illyrian](/wiki/Illyrians "Illyrians") tribes lived in most of the area west of Skopje and [Thracian](/wiki/Thracians "Thracians") groups ([Maedi](/wiki/Maedi "Maedi")) to the east, whilst [Paeonians](/wiki/Paeonians "Paeonians") lived to the south of Skopje.^[\[65\]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDuridanov197517-68)^ The Dardanians had remained independent after the Roman conquest of [Macedon](/wiki/Macedon "Macedon"), and it seems most likely that Dardania lost its independence in 28 BC.^[\[66\]](#cite_note-69)^{#cite_ref-69}  

### Roman Scupi {#Roman_Scupi}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Skopje&action=edit&section=15 "Edit section: Roman Scupi")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/37/Shy_venus_statue_skopje.jpg/150px-Shy_venus_statue_skopje.jpg)](/wiki/File:Shy_venus_statue_skopje.jpg) A "Venus Pudica" found in Scupi, dated from the 2nd century AD^[\[67\]](#cite_note-70)^

Roman expansion east brought Scupi under Roman rule as a colony of [legionaries](/wiki/Legionaries "Legionaries"), mainly veterans of the [Legio VII Claudia](/wiki/Legio_VII_Claudia "Legio VII Claudia") during the reign of Emperor [Domitian](/wiki/Domitian "Domitian") (AD 81--96). However, several legions from the [Roman province of Macedonia](/wiki/Roman_province_of_Macedonia "Roman province of Macedonia") of [Crassus](/wiki/Crassus "Crassus")' army may already have been stationed there around 29--28 BC before the official imperial command was instituted.^[\[68\]](#cite_note-71)^^[\[69\]](#cite_note-72)^ The first mention of the city was made at that period by [Livy](/wiki/Livy "Livy"), who died in AD 17.^[\[18\]](#cite_note-history-19)^ Scupi first served as a military base to maintain peace in the region^[\[64\]](#cite_note-provincial-67)^ and was officially named "*Colonia Flavia Scupinorum*", **Flavia** being the name of the [emperor's dynasty](/wiki/Flavian_dynasty "Flavian dynasty").^[\[70\]](#cite_note-archeology-73)^ Shortly afterwards it became part of the province of [Moesia](/wiki/Moesia "Moesia") during [Augustus](/wiki/Augustus "Augustus")'s rule. After the division of the province by Domitian in AD 86, Scupi was elevated to colonial status and became a seat of government within the new province of [Moesia Superior](/wiki/Moesia_Superior "Moesia Superior"). The district called [Dardania](/wiki/Dardania_(Roman_province) "Dardania (Roman province)") (within Moesia Superior) was formed into a special province by Emperor [Diocletian](/wiki/Diocletian "Diocletian"), with the capital at [Naissus](/wiki/Naissus "Naissus"). In Roman times the eastern part of Dardania, from Scupi to Naissus, remained inhabited mostly by a local population, mainly of [Thracian](/wiki/Thracian "Thracian") origin.^[\[71\]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPapazoglu1978242-74)^{#cite_ref-FOOTNOTEPapazoglu1978242_74-0}

The city's population was very diverse. Engravings on tombstones suggest that only a minority of the population came from [Italia](/wiki/Italia_(ancient_history) "Italia (ancient history)"), whilst many veterans were from [Dalmatia](/wiki/Dalmatia "Dalmatia"), southern [Gaul](/wiki/Gaul "Gaul") and [Syria](/wiki/Syria "Syria"). Because of the ethnic diversity of the population, [Latin](/wiki/Latin_language "Latin language") maintained itself as the main language in the city at the expense of [Greek](/wiki/Ancient_Greek "Ancient Greek"), which was spoken in most of the Moesian and Macedonian cities.^[\[72\]](#cite_note-75)^ During the following centuries, Scupi experienced prosperity. The period from the end of the 3rd century to the end of the 4th century was particularly flourishing.^[\[70\]](#cite_note-archeology-73)^ The first church was founded under the reign of Emperor [Constantine the Great](/wiki/Constantine_the_Great "Constantine the Great") and Scupi became the seat of a [diocese](/wiki/Diocese "Diocese"). In 395, following the division of the [Roman Empire](/wiki/Roman_Empire "Roman Empire") into two, Scupi became part of the [Eastern Roman Empire](/wiki/Eastern_Roman_Empire "Eastern Roman Empire").^[\[18\]](#cite_note-history-19)^{#cite_ref-history_19-2}

An ancient funeral inscription of the [Illyrian](/wiki/Illyrians "Illyrians") tribe [Albanoi](/wiki/Albanoi "Albanoi") was found in [Scupi](/wiki/Scupi "Scupi").^[\[73\]](#cite_note-76)^{#cite_ref-76}

In its zenith, Scupi covered 40 hectares and was closed by a 3.5 m (11 ft) wide wall.^[\[74\]](#cite_note-77)^ It had many monuments, including four [necropoles](/wiki/Necropoles "Necropoles"), a theatre, [thermae](/wiki/Thermae "Thermae"),^[\[70\]](#cite_note-archeology-73)^ and a large Christian [basilica](/wiki/Basilica "Basilica").^[\[75\]](#cite_note-78)^{#cite_ref-78}  

### Middle Ages {#Middle_Ages}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Skopje&action=edit&section=16 "Edit section: Middle Ages")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/94/Skopje_Kale_3.jpg/220px-Skopje_Kale_3.jpg)](/wiki/File:Skopje_Kale_3.jpg) [Skopje Fortress](/wiki/Skopje_Fortress "Skopje Fortress")

In 518, Scupi was destroyed by a violent earthquake,^[\[31\]](#cite_note-damages-32)^ possibly the most devastating the town had ever experienced.^[\[76\]](#cite_note-79)^ At that time, the region was threatened by [Barbarian invasions](/wiki/Barbarian_invasions "Barbarian invasions"), and the city inhabitants had already fled to the forests and mountains before the disaster occurred.^[\[77\]](#cite_note-80)^ The city was eventually rebuilt by [Justinian I](/wiki/Justinian_I "Justinian I"). During his reign, many Byzantine towns were relocated on hills and other easily defendable places to face invasions. It was thus transferred to another site: the promontory on which [Skopje Fortress](/wiki/Skopje_Fortress "Skopje Fortress") stands.^[\[78\]](#cite_note-81)^ Despite this, Scupi was sacked by [Slavs](/wiki/Slavs "Slavs") at the end of the 6th century and the city seems to have fallen under Slavic rule in 595.^[\[79\]](#cite_note-82)^ The Slavic tribe which sacked Scupi was probably the [Berziti](/wiki/Berziti "Berziti"),^[\[18\]](#cite_note-history-19)^ who had invaded the entire Vardar Valley.^[\[80\]](#cite_note-83)^ However, the Slavs did not settle permanently in the region, which had been already plundered and depopulated, but continued south to the Mediterranean coast.^[\[81\]](#cite_note-84)^ After the Slavic invasion it was deserted for some time and is not mentioned during the following centuries.^[\[18\]](#cite_note-history-19)^ Perhaps in the late 7th or the early 8th century the Byzantines again settled at this strategic location. Along with the rest of the Upper Vardar valley it became part of the expanding [Bulgarian Empire](/wiki/First_Bulgarian_Empire "First Bulgarian Empire") in the 830s.^[\[82\]](#cite_note-85)^^[\[83\]](#cite_note-86)^{#cite_ref-86}
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6e/Coronation_of_Emperor_Du%C5%A1an%2C_in_%22The_Slavonic_Epic%22_%281926%29.jpg/220px-Coronation_of_Emperor_Du%C5%A1an%2C_in_%22The_Slavonic_Epic%22_%281926%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Coronation_of_Emperor_Du%C5%A1an,_in_%22The_Slavonic_Epic%22_(1926).jpg) [The coronation](/wiki/Coronation_of_the_Serbian_monarch "Coronation of the Serbian monarch") of Emperor [Stefan Dušan](/wiki/Stefan_Du%C5%A1an "Stefan Dušan") in Skopje^[\[b\]](#cite_note-87)^

Starting from the end of the 10th century Skopje experienced a period of wars and political troubles. It served as the Bulgarian capital from 972 to 992, and [Tsar Samuel](/wiki/Tsar_Samuel "Tsar Samuel") ruled it from 976^[\[84\]](#cite_note-kalemed-88)^ until 1004, when its governor surrendered it to Byzantine Emperor [Basil the Bulgar Slayer](/wiki/Basil_the_Bulgar_Slayer "Basil the Bulgar Slayer") in 1004 in exchange for the titles of [*patrikios*](/wiki/Patrikios "Patrikios") and *[strategos](/wiki/Strategos#Byzantine_use "Strategos")* .^[\[85\]](#cite_note-89)^ It became a centre of a new Byzantine [province](/wiki/Theme_(Byzantine_district) "Theme (Byzantine district)") called [Bulgaria](/wiki/Theme_of_Bulgaria "Theme of Bulgaria").^[\[86\]](#cite_note-90)^ Later Skopje was briefly seized twice by Slavic insurgents who wanted to restore the Bulgarian state. At first in 1040 under [Peter Delyan](/wiki/Peter_Delyan "Peter Delyan")'s command,^[\[87\]](#cite_note-91)^ and in 1072 under the orders of [Georgi Voyteh](/wiki/Georgi_Voyteh "Georgi Voyteh").^[\[88\]](#cite_note-92)^ In 1081, Skopje was captured by [Norman](/wiki/Normans "Normans") troops led by [Robert Guiscard](/wiki/Robert_Guiscard "Robert Guiscard") and the city remained in their hands until 1088. Skopje was subsequently conquered by the Serbian Grand Prince [Vukan](/wiki/Vukan,_Grand_Prince_of_Serbia "Vukan, Grand Prince of Serbia") in 1093, and again by the Normans four years later. However, because of epidemics and food shortage, Normans quickly surrendered to the Byzantines.^[\[89\]](#cite_note-93)^{#cite_ref-93}

During the 12th and 13th centuries, Bulgarians and Serbs took advantage of Byzantine decline to create large kingdoms stretching from the [Danube](/wiki/Danube "Danube") to the [Aegean Sea](/wiki/Aegean_Sea "Aegean Sea"). [Kaloyan](/wiki/Kaloyan_of_Bulgaria "Kaloyan of Bulgaria") brought Skopje back into the re-established [Second Bulgarian Empire](/wiki/Second_Bulgarian_Empire "Second Bulgarian Empire") in 1203^[\[90\]](#cite_note-94)^^[\[91\]](#cite_note-John_Van_Antwerp_Fine_1994_175–184-95)^ until his nephew [Strez](/wiki/Strez "Strez") declared autonomy along the Upper Vardar with Serbian aid only five years later.^[\[92\]](#cite_note-96)^ In 1209, Strez switched allegiances and recognised [Boril of Bulgaria](/wiki/Boril_of_Bulgaria "Boril of Bulgaria") with whom he led a successful joint campaign against Serbia's first internationally recognised King [Stefan Nemanjić](/wiki/Stefan_Nemanji%C4%87 "Stefan Nemanjić").^[\[91\]](#cite_note-John_Van_Antwerp_Fine_1994_175–184-95)^ From 1214 to 1230, Skopje was a part of the Byzantine successor state of [Epirus](/wiki/Despotate_of_Epirus "Despotate of Epirus") before being recaptured by [Ivan Asen II](/wiki/Ivan_Asen_II "Ivan Asen II") and held by Bulgaria until 1246 when the Upper Vardar valley was incorporated once more into another Byzantine [rump state](/wiki/Rump_state "Rump state") -- the [Empire of Nicaea](/wiki/Empire_of_Nicaea "Empire of Nicaea").^[\[93\]](#cite_note-97)^ Byzantine conquest was briefly reversed in 1255 by the [regents](/wiki/Regents "Regents") of the young [Michael Asen I of Bulgaria](/wiki/Michael_Asen_I_of_Bulgaria "Michael Asen I of Bulgaria").^[\[94\]](#cite_note-98)^ Meanwhile, in the parallel civil war for the Crown in [Tarnovo](/wiki/Veliko_Tarnovo "Veliko Tarnovo"), the Skopje [boyar](/wiki/Boyar "Boyar") and grandson of [Stefan Nemanja](/wiki/Stefan_Nemanja "Stefan Nemanja") [Constantine Tikh](/wiki/Constantine_Tikh "Constantine Tikh") gained the upper hand and ruled until the [Uprising of Ivaylo](/wiki/Uprising_of_Ivaylo "Uprising of Ivaylo"), Europe's only successful peasant revolt, led to his deposition from power.{#cite_ref-98}

In 1282, Skopje was captured by Serbian King [Stefan Milutin](/wiki/Stefan_Milutin "Stefan Milutin").^[\[95\]](#cite_note-99)^ Under the political stability of the [Nemanjić](/wiki/Nemanji%C4%87 "Nemanjić") rule, settlement has spread outside the walls of the fortress, towards Gazi Baba hill.^[\[84\]](#cite_note-kalemed-88)^ Churches, monasteries and markets were built and tradesmen from the [Republic of Venice](/wiki/Republic_of_Venice "Republic of Venice") and [Dubrovnik](/wiki/Dubrovnik "Dubrovnik") opened shops. The town greatly benefited from its location near European, Middle Eastern, and African markets. In the 14th century, Skopje became such an important city that King [Stefan Dušan](/wiki/Stephen_Uro%C5%A1_IV_Du%C5%A1an_of_Serbia "Stephen Uroš IV Dušan of Serbia") made it the capital of the [Serbian Empire](/wiki/Serbian_Empire "Serbian Empire"). In 1346, he was crowned as [Emperor of the Serbs and Greeks](/wiki/Emperor_of_the_Serbs_and_Greeks "Emperor of the Serbs and Greeks") in Skopje.^[\[18\]](#cite_note-history-19)^ After his death the Serbian Empire collapsed into several principalities which were unable to defend themselves against the Ottoman Turks. Skopje was first inherited by the [Lordship of Prilep](/wiki/Lordship_of_Prilep "Lordship of Prilep") and finally taken by [Vuk Branković](/wiki/Vuk_Brankovi%C4%87 "Vuk Branković") in the wake of the [Battle of Maritsa](/wiki/Battle_of_Maritsa "Battle of Maritsa") (1371)^[\[96\]](#cite_note-100)^ before becoming part of the [Ottoman Empire](/wiki/Ottoman_Empire "Ottoman Empire") in 1392.^[\[18\]](#cite_note-history-19)^{#cite_ref-history_19-6}

In 1330, Serbian King [Stefan Dečanski](/wiki/Stefan_De%C4%8Danski "Stefan Dečanski") mentioned Albanians as being in the district of Skopje and regularly going to the Fair of [Saint George](/wiki/Saint_George "Saint George") which convened near the city.^[\[97\]](#cite_note-101)^{#cite_ref-101}  

### Ottoman period {#Ottoman_period}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Skopje&action=edit&section=17 "Edit section: Ottoman period")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2e/Prvomajska_proslava_vo_Skopje%2C_1909.jpg/220px-Prvomajska_proslava_vo_Skopje%2C_1909.jpg)](/wiki/File:Prvomajska_proslava_vo_Skopje,_1909.jpg) First May Day celebration of the [Ottoman period](/wiki/Ottoman_Empire "Ottoman Empire") in Skopje, 1909

The [Ottomans](/wiki/Ottoman_Empire "Ottoman Empire") stayed in Skopje for over 520 years and the city's economic life greatly benefited from its position in the middle of [Rumelia](/wiki/Rumelia "Rumelia"), the European province of the Ottomans. The [Stone Bridge](/wiki/Stone_Bridge_(Skopje) "Stone Bridge (Skopje)"), "one of the most imposing stone bridges to be found in Yugoslavia", was reconstructed under the patronage of [Sultan Mehmed II the Conqueror](/wiki/Sultan_Mehmed_II_the_Conqueror "Sultan Mehmed II the Conqueror") between 1451 and 1469.^[\[98\]](#cite_note-jpm-102)^ The Ottomans drastically changed the appearance of the city. They organised the [Bazaar](/wiki/Old_Bazaar,_Skopje "Old Bazaar, Skopje") with its [caravanserais](/wiki/Caravanserais "Caravanserais"), mosques and [baths](/wiki/Turkish_bath "Turkish bath").^[\[99\]](#cite_note-ottoman-103)^{#cite_ref-ottoman_103-0}

In the [cadastral](/wiki/Cadastral "Cadastral") register of 1451--52, the Skopje neighborhood **Gjin-ko** (*Gjinaj*), is mentioned, being named after the medieval Albanian [Gjini family](/wiki/Gjini_family "Gjini family"). The neighbourhood displayed mixed Christian Albanian [anthroponymy](/wiki/Anthroponymy "Anthroponymy") with cases of [Slavicisation](/wiki/Slavicisation "Slavicisation") present (e.g. *Palić*; **Pal** + Slavic suffix *[ić](/wiki/I%C4%87 "Ić")* ).^[\[100\]](#cite_note-104)^ During this time period, a number of [timariots](/wiki/Timariots "Timariots") of the city are recorded as bearing the name *Arnauti* (meaning [Albanian](/wiki/Albanians "Albanians")) alongside a Muslim name, i.e. *Hamza Arnauti**, *Shahin Arnauti*, *Jusuf Arnauti** . Another group bore Slavic Christian names, whilst also carrying bearing the surname *Arbanas*/**Arnaut** , i.e. **Bogdan Arbanas** , **Bogoslav Arbanas** , **Milosh Arbanas** , **Bozhidar Arnaut** , etc. These individuals are not noted as having the Slavic appellatives **došlac** , **prišlac** or **uselica** , which were given by Ottoman authorities to new settlers of a given region, likely indicating they were locals.^[\[101\]](#cite_note-105)^ In the year 1451 or 1453 a neighborhood was registered bearing an [Aromanian](/wiki/Aromanian_language "Aromanian language") name, *Mahalle-i Todor Vlaja-Vlaha*. Amongst the 45 family heads of this neighborhood, Christian Slavic and Albanian anthroponyms were recorded (*Gjon-çe*, son of *Noriç*, *Koljko Bibani* , **Tusho** , son of **Rada** , etc.), whilst a sizeable number of individuals bearing mixed Slavic-[Vlach](/wiki/Vlach "Vlach") anthroponyms are also registered, such as: **Petko** , son of [Vllah](/wiki/Vlachs "Vlachs") (*Iflak* ), **Petru** , son of **David** , **Andreja** , *kozhuhar*, *Nikul Çikun*, etc.^[\[102\]](#cite_note-Rexha_2011_167–218-106)^{#cite_ref-Rexha_2011_167–218_106-0}

In the [mahallah](/wiki/Mahallah "Mahallah") *Ahrijan Hasan* in the year 1451 or 1453, a head of the family from the noble Albanian [Muzaka family](/wiki/Muzaka_family "Muzaka family"), who had converted to Islam, was re-registered amongst the Muslim heads of the family. In the other register of 1467/68, now in the Christian mahallah named *Svetko Samarxhi*, amongst the 29 heads of families with Slavic Christian anthroponyms, a number also carried Albanian anthroponyms.^[\[103\]](#cite_note-107)^ In the neighborhood of *Jazixhi Shahin*, amongst the residents with Muslim names, the head of the family was registered only with the surname *Zenebishi* , without mentioning his social position or his profession, indicating a higher social status. This may suggest a relation to Hasan Bey Zenebishi, a descendant of the [Zenebishi family](/wiki/Zenebishi_family "Zenebishi family") and the [Soubashi](/wiki/Soubashi "Soubashi") of the [Nahiyah](/wiki/Nahiyah "Nahiyah") of [Kalkandelen](/wiki/Kalkandelen "Kalkandelen"). Individuals bearing Albanian anthroponyms, be they in conjunction with Islamic, Slavic or Christian ones, also appear in the neighbourhoods of *Kasim Fakih* , *Dursun Saraç* , *Kujumxhi Mentesheli* , *Çerep, Jandro, Stanimir, Vllah Dançu* and *Rela* .^[\[102\]](#cite_note-Rexha_2011_167–218-106)^ A number of Sipahis were also of Albanian origin, with these individuals holding [timars](/wiki/Timar "Timar") in areas which had a Christian Albanian symbiosis with Slavic anthroponyms in the vicinity of Skopje. The defters noted that these were old [sipahis](/wiki/Sipahis "Sipahis"), likely having been landowners. These individual Sipahis were closely related by descent and blood, and taking account kinship ties, even though they had heterogeneous, Christian, Slavic and Oriental names, they appear to have been Albanians. Some have names indicating their origin, such as *Shimerd Vardarli* from Skopje, making it likely these timariotes were locals.^[\[104\]](#cite_note-108)^{#cite_ref-108}
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0b/Mustafa_Pa%C5%9Fa_Mosque%2C_Skopje.jpg/220px-Mustafa_Pa%C5%9Fa_Mosque%2C_Skopje.jpg)](/wiki/File:Mustafa_Pa%C5%9Fa_Mosque,_Skopje.jpg) The 15th-century [Mustafa Pasha Mosque](/wiki/Mustafa_Pasha_Mosque "Mustafa Pasha Mosque")

Around 1529, the Christians of Skopje were mostly non-converted [Slavs](/wiki/Slavs "Slavs") and [Albanians](/wiki/Albanians "Albanians"), but also [Ragusan](/wiki/Republic_of_Ragusa "Republic of Ragusa") and [Armenian](/wiki/Armenians "Armenians") tradesmen.^[\[105\]](#cite_note-demographic-109)^ [Mustafa Pasha Mosque](/wiki/Mustafa_Pasha_Mosque "Mustafa Pasha Mosque"), built in 1492, is reputed to be "one of the most resplendent sacral Islamic buildings in the Balkans."^[\[106\]](#cite_note-haemus-110)^ In 1535 all churches were demolished by decree of the Ottoman governor.^[\[107\]](#cite_note-oao-111)^^\[*[dubious](/wiki/Wikipedia:Accuracy_dispute#Disputed_statement "Wikipedia:Accuracy dispute") -- [discuss](/wiki/Talk:Skopje#Dubious "Talk:Skopje")*\]^ In 1555, the city was hit by another severe earthquake, collapsing much of the city. The [Old Bazaar of Skopje](/wiki/Old_Bazaar_of_Skopje "Old Bazaar of Skopje"), the columns of the [Stone Bridge](/wiki/Stone_Bridge_(Skopje) "Stone Bridge (Skopje)"), and the [murals](/wiki/Murals "Murals") in the upper parts of the [Church of Saint Panteleimon, Gorno Nerezi](/wiki/Church_of_Saint_Panteleimon,_Gorno_Nerezi "Church of Saint Panteleimon, Gorno Nerezi") were all severely damaged.^[\[108\]](#cite_note-Гергова_100-112)^ Some modern sources estimate this earthquake to have been a Category XII (Extreme) on the [Modified Mercalli intensity scale](/wiki/Modified_Mercalli_intensity_scale "Modified Mercalli intensity scale"), although others believe this is an overestimate.^[\[31\]](#cite_note-damages-32)^{#cite_ref-damages_32-4}

In 1623--1624, [Pjeter Mazreku](/wiki/Pjeter_Mazreku "Pjeter Mazreku"), a Roman Catholic [prelate](/wiki/Prelate "Prelate"), reported the town was inhabited by "Turks (Muslims), the majority of them being [Albanians](/wiki/Albanians "Albanians"), the rest are of Asiatic origin", Mazreku further wrote, "there are also Jews, Serbs and some Greeks in the town".^[\[109\]](#cite_note-113)^^[\[110\]](#cite_note-114)^ In the Ottoman period, *Turk* was used within Christian writings as a name for a Muslim or for Islamised Albanians.^[\[111\]](#cite_note-115)^^[\[112\]](#cite_note-116)^ Sources from the years of 1689--1690 considered the town of Shkupi (Skopje) during those periods as part of [Albania](/wiki/Albania "Albania").^[\[113\]](#cite_note-117)^{#cite_ref-117}

Until the 17th century, Skopje experienced a long golden age. Around 1650, the number of inhabitants in Skopje was between 30,000 and 60,000, and the city contained more than 10,000 houses. It was then one of the only big cities on the territory of future [Yugoslavia](/wiki/Yugoslavia "Yugoslavia"), together with [Belgrade](/wiki/Belgrade "Belgrade") and [Sarajevo](/wiki/Sarajevo "Sarajevo"). At that time, [Dubrovnik](/wiki/Dubrovnik "Dubrovnik"), which was a busy harbour, had not even had 7,000 inhabitants.^[\[114\]](#cite_note-118)^ The city severely suffered from the [Great Turkish War](/wiki/Great_Turkish_War "Great Turkish War") at the end of the 17th century and consequently experienced recession until the 19th century. In 1689, the [Habsburgs](/wiki/Habsburgs "Habsburgs") seized Skopje which was already weakened by a [cholera epidemic](/wiki/Cholera_epidemic "Cholera epidemic").^[\[115\]](#cite_note-119)^ The same day, general [Silvio Piccolomini](/wiki/Enea_Silvio_Piccolomini_(general) "Enea Silvio Piccolomini (general)") began the [Skopje fire of 1689](/wiki/Skopje_fire_of_1689 "Skopje fire of 1689"), attempting to end the epidemic.^[\[18\]](#cite_note-history-19)^ It is however possible that he wanted to avenge damages that the Ottomans caused in the [Battle of Vienna](/wiki/Battle_of_Vienna "Battle of Vienna") in 1683.^[\[116\]](#cite_note-120)^ Skopje burned for two days but the general himself perished of the plague and his leaderless army was routed.^[\[117\]](#cite_note-Mark_Avrum_Ehrlich_2009_980-121)^^[\[118\]](#cite_note-judah09-122)^ The Austrian presence in Macedonia motivated Slav uprisings. Nevertheless, the Austrians left the country within the year and the [Hajduks](/wiki/Hajduks "Hajduks"), the leaders of the uprisings, had to follow them in their retreat north of the Balkans.^[\[18\]](#cite_note-history-19)^ Some were arrested by the Ottomans, such as [Petar Karposh](/wiki/Karposh%27s_Rebellion "Karposh's Rebellion"), who was impaled on Skopje's Stone Bridge.^[\[119\]](#cite_note-123)^{#cite_ref-123}

After the war, Skopje was in ruins. Most of the official buildings were restored or rebuilt, but the city experienced new [plague](/wiki/Plague_(disease) "Plague (disease)") and [cholera](/wiki/Cholera "Cholera") epidemics and many inhabitants emigrated.^[\[105\]](#cite_note-demographic-109)^ [Ottoman Empire](/wiki/Ottoman_Empire "Ottoman Empire") as a whole entered in recession and political decline. Many rebellions and pillages occurred in Macedonia during the 18th century, either led by Ottoman outlaws, [Janissaries](/wiki/Janissaries "Janissaries") or [Hajduks](/wiki/Hajduk "Hajduk").^[\[120\]](#cite_note-rossos08-124)^ An estimation conducted by French officers around 1836 revealed that at that time Skopje only had around 10,000 inhabitants. It was surpassed by two other towns of present-day North Macedonia: [Bitola](/wiki/Bitola "Bitola") (40,000) and [Štip](/wiki/%C5%A0tip "Štip") (15--20,000).^[\[121\]](#cite_note-population1-125)^{#cite_ref-population1_125-0}

Skopje began to recover from decades of decline after 1850. At that time, the city experienced a slow but steady demographic growth, mainly due to the rural exodus of Slavic Macedonians. It was also fuelled by the exodus of Muslims from the [Principalities of Serbia](/wiki/Principality_of_Serbia "Principality of Serbia") and [Bulgaria](/wiki/Principality_of_Bulgaria "Principality of Bulgaria"), which were gaining autonomy and independence from the Empire at that time.^[\[18\]](#cite_note-history-19)^^[\[105\]](#cite_note-demographic-109)^ During the [Tanzimat reforms](/wiki/Tanzimat_reforms "Tanzimat reforms"), [nationalism](/wiki/Nationalism "Nationalism") arose in the Ottoman Empire and in 1870 a new [Bulgarian Exarchate](/wiki/Bulgarian_Exarchate "Bulgarian Exarchate") was established and its separate diocese was created, based on [ethnic identity](/wiki/Ethnic_identity "Ethnic identity"), rather than religious principles.^[\[122\]](#cite_note-126)^ The Slavic population of the bishopric of Skopje voted in 1874 overwhelmingly, by 91% in favour of joining the Exarchate and became part of the [Bulgarian Millet](/wiki/Bulgarian_Millet "Bulgarian Millet").^[\[123\]](#cite_note-127)^ Economic growth was permitted by the construction of the Skopje-[Salonica](/wiki/Salonica "Salonica") railway in 1873.^[\[18\]](#cite_note-history-19)^ The train station was built south of the [Vardar](/wiki/Vardar "Vardar") and this contributed to the relocation of economic activities on that side of the river, which had never been urbanised before.^[\[43\]](#cite_note-reconstruction-44)^ Because of the rural exodus, the share of Christians in the city population increased. Some of the newcomers became part of the local elite and helped to spread nationalist ideas^[\[105\]](#cite_note-demographic-109)^ In 1877, Skopje was chosen as the capital city of the new [Kosovo Vilayet](/wiki/Kosovo_Vilayet "Kosovo Vilayet"), which encompassed present-day [Kosovo](/wiki/Kosovo "Kosovo"), north-western Macedonia and the [Sanjak of Novi Pazar](/wiki/Sanjak_of_Novi_Pazar "Sanjak of Novi Pazar").{#cite_ref-demographic_109-3}

In statistics gathered by Bulgarian ethnographer [Vasil Kanchov](/wiki/Vasil_Kanchov "Vasil Kanchov") in 1900, the City of Skopje was inhabited by 31,900 people, of whom 15,000 were Turks, 13,000 Christian Bulgarians, 1,920 Romani, 800 Jews, 450 Vlachs, 150 Christian Albanians, 50 Christian Greeks, 30 [Circassians](/wiki/Circassians "Circassians") and 500 inhabitants of various other ethnicities.^[\[124\]](#cite_note-128)^ Kanchov wrote in the same year that many Albanians declared themselves as Turks. In Skopje, the population that declared itself Turkish "was of Albanian blood", but it "had been [Turkified](/wiki/Turkified "Turkified") after the Ottoman invasion, including [Skanderbeg](/wiki/Skanderbeg "Skanderbeg")", referring to Islamisation. Bulgarian literary historian [Yordan Ivanov](/wiki/Yordan_Ivanov_(literary_historian) "Yordan Ivanov (literary historian)") wrote in 1915 that Albanians, since they did not have their own alphabet, due to a lack of consolidated national consciousness and influenced by foreign propaganda, declared themselves as Turks, Greeks and Bulgarians, depending on which religion they belonged to. Albanians were losing their mother tongue in Skopje.^[\[125\]](#cite_note-129)^ German linguist [Gustav Weigand](/wiki/Gustav_Weigand "Gustav Weigand") described that Skopje's Muslim population of "Turks" or "Ottomans" during the late Ottoman period were mainly Albanians who spoke Turkish in public and Albanian at home.^[\[126\]](#cite_note-Hart214-130)^ In 1905, the city had 32,000 inhabitants, making it the largest of the vilayet, although closely followed by [Prizren](/wiki/Prizren "Prizren") with its 30,000 inhabitants.^[\[19\]](#cite_note-britannica-20)^ At the beginning of the 20th century, local economy was focused on [dyeing](/wiki/Dyeing "Dyeing"), [weaving](/wiki/Weaving "Weaving"), [tanning](/wiki/Tanning_(leather) "Tanning (leather)"), [ironworks](/wiki/Ironworks "Ironworks") and wine and flour processing.^[\[19\]](#cite_note-britannica-20)^{#cite_ref-britannica_20-2}

Skopje was one of the five main centres of the [Internal Macedonian Revolutionary Organisation](/wiki/Internal_Macedonian_Revolutionary_Organisation "Internal Macedonian Revolutionary Organisation") when it organised the 1903 [Ilinden uprising](/wiki/Ilinden%E2%80%93Preobrazhenie_Uprising "Ilinden–Preobrazhenie Uprising"). Its revolutionary [network in the region](/wiki/Skopje_revolutionary_district "Skopje revolutionary district") led by [Nikola Pushkarov](/wiki/Nikola_Pushkarov "Nikola Pushkarov") was not well-developed and the lack of weapons was a serious problem. At the outbreak of the uprising, the rebel forces derailed a military train.^[\[127\]](#cite_note-131)^ On 3 and 5 August respectively, they attacked an Ottoman unit guarding the bridge on the Vardar river and gave a battle in the "St. Jovan" monastery. In the next few days, the band was pursued by numerous [Bashibozuks](/wiki/Bashibozuk "Bashibozuk") and moved to Bulgaria.{#cite_ref-131}

Following the [Young Turk Revolution](/wiki/Young_Turk_Revolution "Young Turk Revolution") in 1908, the Ottoman Empire experienced democracy and several political parties were created.^[\[18\]](#cite_note-history-19)^ However, some of the policies implemented by the [Young Turks](/wiki/Young_Turks "Young Turks"), such as a tax rise and the interdiction of ethnic-based political parties, discontented minorities. Albanians opposed the nationalist character of the movement and led local uprisings in 1910 and 1912. During the latter, they managed to seize most of Kosovo and took Skopje on 11 August. On 18 August, the insurgents signed the Üsküb agreement which provided for the creation of an autonomous Albanian province and they were amnestied the day later.^[\[128\]](#cite_note-132)^{#cite_ref-132}
