### Balkan Wars to present day {#Balkan_Wars_to_present_day}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Skopje&action=edit&section=18 "Edit section: Balkan Wars to present day")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9a/Shkup1912.jpg/220px-Shkup1912.jpg)](/wiki/File:Shkup1912.jpg) Skopje after being [captured by Albanian revolutionaries](/wiki/Capture_of_%C3%9Cskup "Capture of Üskup") in August 1912 after defeating the Ottoman forces holding the city, later the Ottomans restored power over the city [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3d/PedroIEnUskub11031v.jpg/220px-PedroIEnUskub11031v.jpg)](/wiki/File:PedroIEnUskub11031v.jpg) [Peter I of Serbia](/wiki/Peter_I_of_Serbia "Peter I of Serbia") visiting Skopje in 1914

Following an alliance contracted in 1912, [Bulgaria](/wiki/Bulgaria "Bulgaria"), [Greece](/wiki/Greece "Greece") and [Serbia](/wiki/Serbia "Serbia") declared war on the [Ottoman Empire](/wiki/Ottoman_Empire "Ottoman Empire"). Their goal was to definitively expel the Ottomans from Europe. The [First Balkan War](/wiki/First_Balkan_War "First Balkan War") started on 8 October 1912 and lasted six weeks. Serbians reached Skopje on 26 October. Ottoman forces had left the city the day before.^[\[18\]](#cite_note-history-19)^ During the conflict, [Chetniks](/wiki/Chetniks "Chetniks"), a Serb irregular force razed the Albanian quarter of Skopje and [killed numerous Albanian inhabitants from the city](/wiki/Massacres_of_Albanians_in_the_Balkan_Wars "Massacres of Albanians in the Balkan Wars").^[\[129\]](#cite_note-Michailidis330-133)^ The Serbian annexation led to the exodus of 725 Muslim families which left the city on 27 January 1913. The same year, the city population was evaluated at 37,000 by the Serbian authorities.^[\[105\]](#cite_note-demographic-109)^{#cite_ref-demographic_109-4}
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f9/Centarot_na_Skopje_pred_zemjotresot.jpg/220px-Centarot_na_Skopje_pred_zemjotresot.jpg)](/wiki/File:Centarot_na_Skopje_pred_zemjotresot.jpg) A view of the centre of Skopje in the 1930s [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/56/Nanev_Skopje_1941.jpg/220px-Nanev_Skopje_1941.jpg)](/wiki/File:Nanev_Skopje_1941.jpg) A Bulgarian officer looking at Skopje's centre, April 1941

In 1915, during the [First World War](/wiki/First_World_War "First World War"), Serbian Macedonia was invaded by Bulgaria, which captured Skopje on 22 October 1915. Serbia, allied to the [Triple Entente](/wiki/Triple_Entente "Triple Entente"), was helped by France, [Britain](/wiki/United_Kingdom_of_Great_Britain_and_Ireland "United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland"), [Greece](/wiki/Greece "Greece"), and Italy, which formed the [Macedonian front](/wiki/Macedonian_front "Macedonian front"). Following a great Allied offensive in 1918, the [Armée française d'Orient](/wiki/Arm%C3%A9e_fran%C3%A7aise_d%27Orient "Armée française d'Orient") reached Skopje 29 September and took the city by surprise.^[\[130\]](#cite_note-134)^ After the end of the World War, Vardar Macedonia became part of the new [Kingdom of Serbs, Croats, and Slovenes](/wiki/Kingdom_of_Yugoslavia "Kingdom of Yugoslavia"), which became "Kingdom of Yugoslavia" in 1929.^[\[18\]](#cite_note-history-19)^ A mostly foreign [ethnic Serb](/wiki/Serbs "Serbs") ruling class gained control, imposing large-scale repression.^[\[131\]](#cite_note-135)^ The policies of de-Bulgarisation and assimilation were pursued.^[\[132\]](#cite_note-136)^ At that time part of the young locals, repressed by the Serbs, tried to find a separate way of ethnic Macedonian development.^[\[133\]](#cite_note-137)^ In 1931, in a move to formally decentralise the country, Skopje was named the capital of the [Vardar Banovina](/wiki/Vardar_Banovina "Vardar Banovina") of the [Kingdom of Yugoslavia](/wiki/Kingdom_of_Yugoslavia "Kingdom of Yugoslavia"). Until the [Second World War](/wiki/Second_World_War "Second World War"), Skopje experienced strong economic growth, and its population increased. The city had 41,066 inhabitants in 1921, 64,807 in 1931, and 80,000 in 1941.^[\[105\]](#cite_note-demographic-109)^ Although in an underdeveloped region, it attracted wealthy Serbs who opened businesses and contributed to the modernisation of the city.^[\[134\]](#cite_note-colophon-138)^ In 1941, Skopje had 45 factories, half of the industry in the whole of Socialist Macedonia.^[\[135\]](#cite_note-139)^{#cite_ref-139}
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e9/Skopsko_Kale%2C_stara.jpg/220px-Skopsko_Kale%2C_stara.jpg)](/wiki/File:Skopsko_Kale,_stara.jpg) The national theatre and the fortress around 1920

In 1941, during the Second World War, Yugoslavia was invaded by [Nazi Germany](/wiki/Nazi_Germany "Nazi Germany"). Germans seized Skopje on 8 April^[\[18\]](#cite_note-history-19)^ and left it to their Bulgarian allies on 22 April 1941.^[\[136\]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTERamet2006139-140)^ To ensure the [Bulgarisation](/wiki/Bulgarisation "Bulgarisation") of the society, authorities closed Serbian schools and churches, opening new schools and a higher education institute, the King Boris University.^[\[137\]](#cite_note-141)^ The 4,000 Jews of Skopje were all deported in 1943 to the [Treblinka extermination camp](/wiki/Treblinka_extermination_camp "Treblinka extermination camp") where almost all of them were killed.^[\[138\]](#cite_note-jews_p._47-142)^{#cite_ref-jews_p._47_142-0}
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c9/Chento_Vlahov_Apostolski_-_Parading_in_liberated_Skopje.jpg/220px-Chento_Vlahov_Apostolski_-_Parading_in_liberated_Skopje.jpg)](/wiki/File:Chento_Vlahov_Apostolski_-_Parading_in_liberated_Skopje.jpg) [Čento](/wiki/Metodija_Andonov-%C4%8Cento "Metodija Andonov-Čento"), [Dimitar Vlahov](/wiki/Dimitar_Vlahov "Dimitar Vlahov") and [Mihajlo Apostolski](/wiki/Mihajlo_Apostolski "Mihajlo Apostolski") parading in liberated Skopje, November 1944

[Skopje was liberated](/wiki/Capture_of_Skopje_(1944) "Capture of Skopje (1944)") on 13 November 1944 by units of the [Bulgarian People's Army](/wiki/Bulgarian_People%27s_Army "Bulgarian People's Army") (Bulgaria having switched sides in the war [in September](/wiki/Bulgarian_coup_d%27%C3%A9tat_of_1944 "Bulgarian coup d'état of 1944")) aided by [Yugoslav Partisans](/wiki/Yugoslav_Partisans "Yugoslav Partisans") of the [Macedonian National Liberation Army](/wiki/Macedonian_National_Liberation_Army "Macedonian National Liberation Army").^[\[139\]](#cite_note-143)^^[\[140\]](#cite_note-144)^^[\[141\]](#cite_note-145)^^[\[142\]](#cite_note-146)^ Skopje became the capital city of the newly proclaimed [Democratic Federal Macedonia](/wiki/Democratic_Federal_Macedonia "Democratic Federal Macedonia") as set up by the [ASNOM](/wiki/Anti-fascist_Assembly_for_the_National_Liberation_of_Macedonia "Anti-fascist Assembly for the National Liberation of Macedonia") on 2 August 1944 in the [Bulgarian occupation zone in Yugoslavia](/wiki/Bulgaria_during_World_War_II "Bulgaria during World War II").{#cite_ref-146}

After [World War II](/wiki/World_War_II "World War II"), Skopje greatly benefited from [Socialist Yugoslav](/wiki/SFR_Yugoslavia "SFR Yugoslavia") policies which encouraged industry and the development of Macedonian cultural institutions. Consequently, Skopje became home to a national library, a philharmonic orchestra, a university, and the Macedonian Academy of Sciences and Arts. However, its post-war development was altered by the [1963 earthquake](/wiki/1963_Skopje_earthquake "1963 Skopje earthquake") which occurred on 26 July. Although relatively weak in magnitude, it caused enormous damage in the city and can be compared to the [1960 Agadir earthquake](/wiki/1960_Agadir_earthquake "1960 Agadir earthquake").^[\[143\]](#cite_note-147)^ The disaster killed 1,070 people, injuring 3,300 others. 16,000 people were buried alive in ruins and 70% of the population lost their home.^[\[42\]](#cite_note-post-43)^ Many educational facilities, factories and historical buildings were destroyed.^[\[43\]](#cite_note-reconstruction-44)^{#cite_ref-reconstruction_44-3}
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/da/US_army_in_Skopje_1963.jpg/220px-US_army_in_Skopje_1963.jpg)](/wiki/File:US_army_in_Skopje_1963.jpg) American soldiers in Skopje after the [1963 earthquake](/wiki/1963_Skopje_earthquake "1963 Skopje earthquake") [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/af/Centar%2C_Skopje_1000%2C_Macedonia_%28FYROM%29_-_panoramio_%28151%29.jpg/220px-Centar%2C_Skopje_1000%2C_Macedonia_%28FYROM%29_-_panoramio_%28151%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Centar,_Skopje_1000,_Macedonia_(FYROM)_-_panoramio_(151).jpg) Monument to the Macedonian partisans -- Liberators of Skopje, next to the Government building

After the [earthquake](/wiki/1963_Skopje_earthquake "1963 Skopje earthquake"), reconstruction was quick. It had a deep psychological impact on the population because neighbourhoods were split and people were relocated to new houses and buildings they were not familiar with.^[\[42\]](#cite_note-post-43)^ Many Albanians, some from Kosovo participated in the reconstruction effort.^[\[144\]](#cite_note-Ragaru535-148)^ Reconstruction was finished by 1980, even if many elements were never built because funds were exhausted.^[\[43\]](#cite_note-reconstruction-44)^ Skopje cityscape was drastically changed and the city became a true example of [modernist architecture](/wiki/Modernist_architecture "Modernist architecture"). Demographic growth was very important after 1963, and Skopje had 408,100 inhabitants in 1981.^[\[145\]](#cite_note-149)^ After 1963, rural youth migrated to Skopje and were involved in the reconstruction process resulting in a large growth of the urban Macedonian population.^[\[146\]](#cite_note-Neofotistos893-150)^^[\[147\]](#cite_note-Thiessen10-151)^^[\[148\]](#cite_note-Brown417442-152)^ The Albanian population of Skopje also increased as people from the northern villages migrated to the city and others came from Kosovo either to provide manpower for reconstruction or fled the deteriorating political situation, especially during the 1990s.^[\[144\]](#cite_note-Ragaru535-148)^ However, during the 1980s and the 1990s, the country experienced inflation and recession and the local economy heavily suffered. The situation became better during the 2000s thanks to new investments. Many landmarks were restored and the "[Skopje 2014](/wiki/Skopje_2014 "Skopje 2014")" project renewed the appearance of the city centre.{#cite_ref-Ragaru535_148-1}  

Emblems {#Emblems}
------------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Skopje&action=edit&section=19 "Edit section: Emblems")\]  
Main articles: [Flag of Skopje](/wiki/Flag_of_Skopje "Flag of Skopje") and [Coat of arms of Skopje](/wiki/Coat_of_arms_of_Skopje "Coat of arms of Skopje")

The [Flag of Skopje](/wiki/Flag_of_Skopje "Flag of Skopje")^[\[149\]](#cite_note-153)^ is a red banner in proportions 1:2 with a gold-coloured [coat of arms of the city](/wiki/Coat_of_arms_of_Skopje "Coat of arms of Skopje") positioned in the upper-left corner. It is either vertical or horizontal, but the [vertical version](/wiki/Vertical_flag "Vertical flag") was the first to be used.{#cite_ref-153}

The coat of arms of the city was adopted in the 1950s. It depicts the [Stone Bridge](/wiki/Stone_Bridge_(Skopje) "Stone Bridge (Skopje)") with the [Vardar](/wiki/Vardar "Vardar") river, the [Kale Fortress](/wiki/Skopje_Fortress "Skopje Fortress") and the snow-capped peaks of the [Šar mountains](/wiki/%C5%A0ar_mountains "Šar mountains").^[\[150\]](#cite_note-154)^{#cite_ref-154}  

Administration {#Administration}
--------------------------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Skopje&action=edit&section=20 "Edit section: Administration")\]  

### Status {#Status}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Skopje&action=edit&section=21 "Edit section: Status")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a2/MKD_muni_nonn%28Skopje%29.png/220px-MKD_muni_nonn%28Skopje%29.png)](/wiki/File:MKD_muni_nonn(Skopje).png) Greater Skopje amongst the [municipalities of North Macedonia](/wiki/Municipalities_of_North_Macedonia "Municipalities of North Macedonia")

Being the capital and largest city of North Macedonia, Skopje enjoys a particular status granted by law. The last revision of its status was made in 2004. Since then, the City of Skopje has been divided into 10 municipalities which all have a council and a mayor, like all of the country's municipalities. Municipalities only deal with matters specific of their territory, and the City of Skopje deals with matters that concern all of them, or that cannot be divided between two or more municipalities.^[\[151\]](#cite_note-local-155)^{#cite_ref-local_155-0}

The City of Skopje is part of the [Skopje Statistical Region](/wiki/Skopje_Statistical_Region "Skopje Statistical Region"), which has no political or administrative power.^[\[151\]](#cite_note-local-155)^{#cite_ref-local_155-1}  

### City Council {#City_Council}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Skopje&action=edit&section=22 "Edit section: City Council")\]

The City Council consists of 45 members who serve a four-year term. It primarily deals with budget, global orientations and relations between the city and the government. Several commissions exist to treat more specific topics, such as urbanism, finances, environment of local development.^[\[152\]](#cite_note-council-156)^ The President of the council is elected by the Council Members. Since 2021 the president has been Trajko Slaveski, member of [VMRO-DPMNE](/wiki/VMRO-DPMNE "VMRO-DPMNE").^[\[153\]](#cite_note-157)^^[\[152\]](#cite_note-council-156)^{#cite_ref-council_156-1}

Following the 2021 local elections, the City Council is constituted as follows:^[\[152\]](#cite_note-council-156)^^[\[154\]](#cite_note-158)^{#cite_ref-158}

### Mayor {#Mayor}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Skopje&action=edit&section=23 "Edit section: Mayor")\]

The [Mayor of Skopje](/wiki/Mayor_of_Skopje "Mayor of Skopje") is elected every four years. The mayor represents the City of Skopje and can submit ideas to the council, manages the administrative bodies and their officials.^[\[155\]](#cite_note-159)^{#cite_ref-159}  

### Municipalities {#Municipalities}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Skopje&action=edit&section=24 "Edit section: Municipalities")\]

Skopje was first divided into administrative units in 1945, but the first municipalities were created in 1976. They were five: [Centar](/wiki/Centar_Municipality_(Skopje) "Centar Municipality (Skopje)"), [Čair](/wiki/%C4%8Cair_municipality "Čair municipality"), [Karpoš](/wiki/Karpo%C5%A1_municipality "Karpoš municipality"), [Gazi Baba](/wiki/Gazi_Baba_municipality "Gazi Baba municipality") and [Kisela Voda](/wiki/Kisela_Voda_municipality "Kisela Voda municipality"). After the 1991 independence of the country, power was centralised and municipalities lost much of their competences. A 1996 law restored them and created two new municipalities: [Ǵorče Petrov](/wiki/%C7%B4or%C4%8De_Petrov_municipality "Ǵorče Petrov municipality") and [Šuto Orizari](/wiki/%C5%A0uto_Orizari_municipality "Šuto Orizari municipality"). After the [insurgency between Albanian rebels and Macedonian forces](/wiki/2001_insurgency_in_Macedonia "2001 insurgency in Macedonia") in 2001, a new law was enacted in 2004 to incorporate [Saraj Municipality](/wiki/Saraj_Municipality "Saraj Municipality") into the City of Skopje. Saraj is mostly populated by Albanians and, since then, Albanians represent more than 20% of the city population. Thus Albanian became the second official language of the city administration, something which was one of the claims of the Albanian rebels. The same year, [Aerodrom Municipality](/wiki/Aerodrom_Municipality_(Skopje) "Aerodrom Municipality (Skopje)") separated itself from Kisela Voda, and [Butel Municipality](/wiki/Butel_Municipality "Butel Municipality") from Čair.^[\[151\]](#cite_note-local-155)^{#cite_ref-local_155-2}

Municipalities are administered by a council of 23 members elected every four years. They also have a mayor and several departments (education, culture, finances...). The mayor primarily deals with these departments.^[\[156\]](#cite_note-160)^{#cite_ref-160}

Economy {#Economy}
------------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Skopje&action=edit&section=25 "Edit section: Economy")\]  

### Economic weight {#Economic_weight}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Skopje&action=edit&section=26 "Edit section: Economic weight")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e1/Skopje_X9.JPG/220px-Skopje_X9.JPG)](/wiki/File:Skopje_X9.JPG) The small business district

Skopje is a medium city at the European level. Being the capital and largest city of North Macedonia, Skopje concentrates a large share of the national economy. The [Skopje Statistical Region](/wiki/Skopje_Statistical_Region "Skopje Statistical Region"), which encompasses the City of Skopje and some neighbouring municipalities, produces 45.5% of the Macedonian GDP.^[\[157\]](#cite_note-161)^ In 2009, the regional GDP per capita amounted to US$6,565, or 155% of the Macedonian GDP per capita.^[\[158\]](#cite_note-162)^ This figure is, however, smaller than the one of neighboring [Sofia](/wiki/Sofia "Sofia") (US$10,106),^[\[159\]](#cite_note-163)^ [Sarajevo](/wiki/Sarajevo "Sarajevo") (US$10,048)^[\[160\]](#cite_note-164)^ or [Belgrade](/wiki/Belgrade "Belgrade") (US$7,983),^[\[161\]](#cite_note-165)^ but higher than the one of [Tirana](/wiki/Tirana "Tirana") (US$4,126).^[\[162\]](#cite_note-166)^{#cite_ref-166}

Because there are no other large cities in the country, and because of political and economic centralisation, a large number of Macedonians living outside of Skopje work in the capital city. The dynamism of the city also encourages [rural exodus](/wiki/Rural_exodus "Rural exodus"), not only from North Macedonia, but also from [Kosovo](/wiki/Kosovo "Kosovo"), [Albania](/wiki/Albania "Albania") and Southern [Serbia](/wiki/Serbia "Serbia").^[\[163\]](#cite_note-quality-167)^{#cite_ref-quality_167-0}  

### Firms and activities {#Firms_and_activities}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Skopje&action=edit&section=27 "Edit section: Firms and activities")\]

In 2009, Skopje had 26,056 firms but only 145 of them had a large size. The large majority of them are either small (12,017) or very small (13,625).^[\[164\]](#cite_note-168)^ A large share of the firms deal with trade of goods (9,758), 3,839 are specialised in business and real estate, and 2,849 are manufacturers.^[\[165\]](#cite_note-169)^ Although few in number, large firms account for 51% of the local production outside finance.^[\[53\]](#cite_note-region-54)^{#cite_ref-region_54-2}
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b5/Skopje_X132.JPG/220px-Skopje_X132.JPG)](/wiki/File:Skopje_X132.JPG) The [Imperial Tobacco](/wiki/Imperial_Tobacco "Imperial Tobacco") plant

The city industry is dominated by food processing, textile, printing and metal processing. In 2012, it accounted for 30% of the city's GDP.^[\[53\]](#cite_note-region-54)^ Most of the industrial areas are in [Gazi Baba municipality](/wiki/Gazi_Baba_municipality "Gazi Baba municipality"), on the major routes and rail lines to [Belgrade](/wiki/Belgrade "Belgrade") and [Thessaloniki](/wiki/Thessaloniki "Thessaloniki").^[\[166\]](#cite_note-170)^ Notably, the [ArcelorMittal](/wiki/ArcelorMittal "ArcelorMittal"), Makstil steel plants and the Skopje Brewery are there. Other zones are between Aerodrom and Kisela Voda, along the railway to [Greece](/wiki/Greece "Greece"). These zones comprise Alkaloid Skopje (pharmaceuticals), Rade Končar (electrical supplies), [Imperial Tobacco](/wiki/Imperial_Tobacco "Imperial Tobacco"), and Ohis (fertilisers). Two [special economic zones](/wiki/Special_economic_zone "Special economic zone") also exist, around the airport and the Okta refinery. They have attracted several foreign companies, such as [Johnson Controls](/wiki/Johnson_Controls "Johnson Controls"), [Johnson Matthey](/wiki/Johnson_Matthey "Johnson Matthey") and [Van Hool](/wiki/Van_Hool "Van Hool").^[\[167\]](#cite_note-171)^{#cite_ref-171}

As the country's financial capital, Skopje is the seat of the [Macedonian Stock Exchange](/wiki/Macedonian_Stock_Exchange "Macedonian Stock Exchange"), of the [National Bank](/wiki/National_Bank_of_North_Macedonia "National Bank of North Macedonia"), and of most of the country's banking, insurance, and telecommunication companies, such as [Makedonski Telekom](/wiki/Makedonski_Telekom "Makedonski Telekom"), [Komercijalna banka Skopje](/wiki/Komercijalna_banka_Skopje "Komercijalna banka Skopje") and [Stopanska Banka](/wiki/Stopanska_Banka "Stopanska Banka"). The services sector produces 60% of the city GDP.^[\[53\]](#cite_note-region-54)^{#cite_ref-region_54-4}
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ab/Zeleno_pazarce_-_Flickr_-_ImogenX_%289%29.jpg/220px-Zeleno_pazarce_-_Flickr_-_ImogenX_%289%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Zeleno_pazarce_-_Flickr_-_ImogenX_(9).jpg) The Zelen Pazar ("green market")

Besides many small traditional shops, Skopje has two large markets, the "Zelen Pazar" (green market) and the "Bit Pazar" (flea market). They are both considered local institutions.^[\[50\]](#cite_note-thiesen57-51)^ However, since the 1970s, retailing has largely been modernised and Skopje now has many supermarkets and shopping centres. The largest, Skopje City Mall, opened in 2012. It comprises a [Carrefour](/wiki/Carrefour "Carrefour") hypermarket, 130 shops and a cinema, and employs 2,000 people.^[\[168\]](#cite_note-172)^{#cite_ref-172}
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e3/Skopje_City_Mall.jpg/220px-Skopje_City_Mall.jpg)](/wiki/File:Skopje_City_Mall.jpg) Skopje City Mall  

### Employment {#Employment}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Skopje&action=edit&section=28 "Edit section: Employment")\]

51% of the Skopje active population is employed in small firms. 52% of the population work in the services sector, 34% in industry, and the remaining is mainly employed in administration.^[\[53\]](#cite_note-region-54)^{#cite_ref-region_54-5}

The unemployment rate for the [Skopje Statistical Region](/wiki/Skopje_Statistical_Region "Skopje Statistical Region") was at 27% in 2009, three points under the national rate (30%). The neighbouring [Polog Region](/wiki/Polog_Statistical_Region "Polog Statistical Region") had a similar rate, but the less affected region was the [South-West](/wiki/Southwestern_Statistical_Region "Southwestern Statistical Region"), with 22%.^[\[169\]](#cite_note-173)^ Unemployment in Skopje mainly affects men, who represent 56% of job-seekers, people between 25 and 44 years old (45% of job-seekers), and non-qualified people (43%).^[\[53\]](#cite_note-region-54)^ Unemployment also concerns [Roma people](/wiki/Roma_people "Roma people"), who represent 4.63% of the city population but affects 70% of the active population in the community.^[\[51\]](#cite_note-roma-52)^{#cite_ref-roma_52-1}

The average net monthly wage in Skopje was at €400 in October 2010, which represented 120% of the national figure.^[\[170\]](#cite_note-brutno-174)^ The average wage in Skopje was then lower than in [Sarajevo](/wiki/Sarajevo "Sarajevo") (€522),^[\[171\]](#cite_note-175)^ [Sofia](/wiki/Sofia "Sofia") (€436),^[\[172\]](#cite_note-176)^ and in [Belgrade](/wiki/Belgrade "Belgrade") (€440).^[\[173\]](#cite_note-177)^{#cite_ref-177}

### Population {#Population}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Skopje&action=edit&section=30 "Edit section: Population")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2b/Ulica_Makedonija.JPG/220px-Ulica_Makedonija.JPG)](/wiki/File:Ulica_Makedonija.JPG) People on Macedonia street, the main pedestrian axis of the city

According to the results of the 2021 census, the City of Skopje had 526,502 inhabitants.^[\[2\]](#cite_note-stats2-2)^ Skopje's employment area covers a large part of the country, including [Veles](/wiki/Veles_(city) "Veles (city)"), [Kumanovo](/wiki/Kumanovo "Kumanovo") and [Tetovo](/wiki/Tetovo "Tetovo"), and totaling more than one million inhabitants.^[\[176\]](#cite_note-trace-180)^{#cite_ref-trace_180-0}

Skopje contains roughly a quarter of North Macedonia's population. The second most populous municipality, [Kumanovo](/wiki/Kumanovo "Kumanovo"), had 107,632 inhabitants in 2011,^[\[177\]](#cite_note-stats-181)^ and an [urban unit](/wiki/Urban_unit "Urban unit") of 76,272 inhabitants in 2002.^[\[49\]](#cite_note-stats1-50)^{#cite_ref-stats1_50-4}

Before the [Austro-Turkish war](/wiki/Ottoman%E2%80%93Habsburg_wars "Ottoman–Habsburg wars") and the [1689 Great Fire](/wiki/Fire_of_Skopje_1689 "Fire of Skopje 1689"), Skopje was one of the biggest cities in the [Balkans](/wiki/Balkans "Balkans"), with a population estimated between 30,000 and 60,000 inhabitants.^[\[18\]](#cite_note-history-19)^ After the fire set by the retreating Austrian forces, it experienced a long period of decline and only had 10,000 inhabitants in 1836.^[\[121\]](#cite_note-population1-125)^ However, the population started to rise again after 1850 and reached 32,000 inhabitants in 1905.^[\[19\]](#cite_note-britannica-20)^ In the 20th century, Skopje was one of the fastest-growing cities in [Yugoslavia](/wiki/Yugoslavia "Yugoslavia"), and it had 448,200 inhabitants in 1981. Since then, the demographic growth has continued at a steady rate.^[\[174\]](#cite_note-jasna-178)^{#cite_ref-jasna_178-1}  

### Ethnic groups {#Ethnic_groups}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Skopje&action=edit&section=31 "Edit section: Ethnic groups")\]

Ethnic groups in Greater Skopje consist of the following:

| [Turks](/wiki/Turkish_people "Turkish people")                               | 8,595   | 1.70  | 8,524   | 1.62  |
| [Roma](/wiki/Romani_people "Romani people")                                  | 23,475  | 4.63  | 18,498  | 3.51  |
| [Vlachs](/wiki/Vlachs "Vlachs")                                              | 2,557   | 0.50  | 2,778   | 0.53  |
| [Serbs](/wiki/Serbs "Serbs")                                                 | 14,298  | 2.82  | 9,478   | 1.80  |

| Administrative sources                                                       | N/A     | N/A   | 44,175  | 8.39  |

Skopje, just like North Macedonia as a whole, is characterised by a large ethnic diversity. The city is in a region where Macedonians and Albanians meet, and it has had populations of Bulgarians, Romani, Turks, Jews, and Serbs through its history. Skopje was mainly a Muslim city until the 19th century when large numbers of Christians started to settle there. According to the 2021 census, Macedonians were the largest ethnic group in Skopje, with 309,107 inhabitants, or 58.71% of the population. Then came Albanians with 120,293 inhabitants (22.85%), Roma people with 18,498 (3.51%), Serbs (9,478 inhabitants), Turks (8,524), Bosniaks (7,365) and [Aromanians](/wiki/Aromanians "Aromanians") (also known as "Vlachs", 2,778). 6,284 people did not belong to any of these groups.^[\[2\]](#cite_note-stats2-2)^{#cite_ref-stats2_2-5}

Macedonians form an overwhelming majority of the population in the municipalities of [Aerodrom](/wiki/Aerodrom_Municipality_(Skopje) "Aerodrom Municipality (Skopje)"), [Centar](/wiki/Centar_Municipality_(Skopje) "Centar Municipality (Skopje)"), [Ǵorče Petrov](/wiki/%C7%B4or%C4%8De_Petrov_municipality "Ǵorče Petrov municipality"), [Karpoš](/wiki/Karpo%C5%A1_municipality "Karpoš municipality") and [Kisela Voda](/wiki/Kisela_Voda_municipality "Kisela Voda municipality"), which are all south of the [Vardar](/wiki/Vardar "Vardar").^[\[178\]](#cite_note-Ragaru536-182)^ They also form a majority in [Butel](/wiki/Butel_municipality "Butel municipality")^[\[179\]](#cite_note-Ragaru536537-183)^ and [Gazi Baba](/wiki/Gazi_Baba_municipality "Gazi Baba municipality") which are north of the river. Albanians form a majority in [Čair](/wiki/%C4%8Cair_municipality "Čair municipality") which roughly corresponds to the [Old Bazaar](/wiki/Old_Bazaar,_Skopje "Old Bazaar, Skopje"), and in [Saraj](/wiki/Saraj_municipality "Saraj municipality").^[\[180\]](#cite_note-Ragaru535537-184)^ They form a large minority in Butel^[\[179\]](#cite_note-Ragaru536537-183)^ and Gazi Baba. [Šuto Orizari](/wiki/%C5%A0uto_Orizari_municipality "Šuto Orizari municipality"), on the northern edge of the city, is predominantly Roma.^[\[49\]](#cite_note-stats1-50)^ When an ethnic minority forms at least 20% of the population in a municipality, its language can become official on the local level. Thus, in Čair and Saraj schools and administration use Albanian, and Romani in Šuto Orizari.^[\[181\]](#cite_note-185)^ The latter is the only municipality in the world where Romani is an official language.^[\[51\]](#cite_note-roma-52)^{#cite_ref-roma_52-2}

Relations between the two largest groups, Macedonians and Albanians, are sometimes difficult, as in the rest of the country. Each group tolerates the other but they tend to avoid each other and live in what can appear as two parallel worlds.^[\[182\]](#cite_note-186)^ Both Macedonians and Albanians view themselves each as the original population of Skopje and the other as newcomers.^[\[183\]](#cite_note-StefoskaStojanov363-187)^^[\[144\]](#cite_note-Ragaru535-148)^^[\[146\]](#cite_note-Neofotistos893-150)^ The Roma minority is on its side very deprived. Its exact size is not known because many Macedonian Roma declare themselves as belonging to other ethnic groups or simply avoid censuses. However, even if official figures are underestimated, Skopje is the city in the world with the largest Roma population.^[\[51\]](#cite_note-roma-52)^{#cite_ref-roma_52-3}  

### Religion {#Religion}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Skopje&action=edit&section=32 "Edit section: Religion")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/be/Presveta_Bogordica_od_Skopje_4.JPG/220px-Presveta_Bogordica_od_Skopje_4.JPG)](/wiki/File:Presveta_Bogordica_od_Skopje_4.JPG) The church of the Nativity of the Virgin Mary

Religious affiliation is diverse: Macedonians, Serbs, and Aromanians are mainly Orthodox, with the majority affiliated to the [Macedonian Orthodox Church](/wiki/Macedonian_Orthodox_Church_%E2%80%93_Ohrid_Archbishopric "Macedonian Orthodox Church – Ohrid Archbishopric"); Turks are almost entirely Muslim; those of Albanian ethnicity are largely Muslim, although Skopje also has a sizeable [Roman Catholic](/wiki/Roman_Catholic "Roman Catholic") Albanian minority, into which [Mother Teresa](/wiki/Mother_Teresa "Mother Teresa") was born; the Roma (Gypsies) represent a mixture (in almost equal numbers) of Muslim and Orthodox religious heritage.^[\[184\]](#cite_note-188)^{#cite_ref-188}

According to the 2002 census, 68.5% of the population of Skopje belonged to the [Eastern Orthodox Church](/wiki/Eastern_Orthodox_Church "Eastern Orthodox Church"), whilst 28.6% belonged to [Islam](/wiki/Islam "Islam"). The city also had Catholic (0.5%) and [Protestant](/wiki/Protestant "Protestant") (0.04%) minorities.^[\[185\]](#cite_note-189)^ The Catholics are served by the Latin [bishopric of Skopje](/wiki/Roman_Catholic_Diocese_of_Skopje "Roman Catholic Diocese of Skopje"), in which is also vested the [Byzantine Catholic Apostolic Exarchate of Macedonia](/wiki/Byzantine_Catholic_Apostolic_Exarchate_of_Macedonia "Byzantine Catholic Apostolic Exarchate of Macedonia").{#cite_ref-189}

Until [World War II](/wiki/World_War_II "World War II"), Skopje had a significant Jewish minority which mainly descended from Spanish [Sephardis](/wiki/Sephardi_Jews "Sephardi Jews") who had escaped the [Inquisition](/wiki/Inquisition "Inquisition"). The community comprised 2,424 members in 1939 (representing about 3% of the city population), but most of them were deported and killed by [Nazis](/wiki/Nazis "Nazis"). After the war, most of the survivors settled in Israel.^[\[117\]](#cite_note-Mark_Avrum_Ehrlich_2009_980-121)^^[\[186\]](#cite_note-190)^ Today the city has around 200 Jewish inhabitants (about 0.04% of the population).{#cite_ref-190}

Because of its 520-year Ottoman past, and the fact that many of its inhabitants today are Muslims, Skopje has more mosques than churches. Religious communities often complain about the lack of infrastructure and new places of worship are often built.^[\[187\]](#cite_note-191)^ Skopje is the seat of many Macedonian religious organisations, such as the [Macedonian Orthodox Church](/wiki/Macedonian_Orthodox_Church "Macedonian Orthodox Church") and the Islamic Religious Union of Macedonia. It has an Orthodox cathedral and seminary, several [madrasahs](/wiki/Madrasah "Madrasah"), a Roman Catholic cathedral and a synagogue.^[\[188\]](#cite_note-192)^{#cite_ref-192}  

### Health {#Health}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Skopje&action=edit&section=33 "Edit section: Health")\]

Skopje has several public and private hospitals and specialised medical institutions, such as the [Filip II Hospital](/wiki/Filip_II_Hospital,_Skopje "Filip II Hospital, Skopje"), a psychiatric hospital, two obstetric hospitals, a gerontology hospital, and institutes for respiratory and ocular diseases.^[\[189\]](#cite_note-193)^ In 2012, Skopje had a ratio of one physician per 251.6 inhabitants, a figure higher than the national ratio (one per 370.9). The ratio of medical specialists was also higher than in the rest of the country. However, the ratio of hospital beds, pharmacists and dentists was lower in Skopje.^[\[190\]](#cite_note-health-194)^ The population in Skopje enjoys better health standards than other Macedonians. In 2010, the mortality rate was at 8.6‰ in Skopje and 9.3‰ on the national level. The infant mortality rate was at 6.8‰ in Skopje and 7.6‰ in North Macedonia.^[\[190\]](#cite_note-health-194)^{#cite_ref-health_194-1}  

### Education {#Education}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Skopje&action=edit&section=34 "Edit section: Education")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b9/Ss._Cyril_and_Methodius_University_in_Skopje_6.jpg/220px-Ss._Cyril_and_Methodius_University_in_Skopje_6.jpg)](/wiki/File:Ss._Cyril_and_Methodius_University_in_Skopje_6.jpg) Faculty of Economics, [Ss. Cyril and Methodius University](/wiki/Ss._Cyril_and_Methodius_University_of_Skopje "Ss. Cyril and Methodius University of Skopje").

Skopje's citizenry is generally more educated than the rest of the country. 16% of Skopjans have graduated from university in contrast to 10% for the rest of the country. The number of people with a complete lack of education or ones who received a partial education is lower in Skopje at 9% compared to the provincial average of 17%. 80% of Macedonian citizens who hold a PhD take up residence in Skopje.^[\[191\]](#cite_note-strategija-195)^{#cite_ref-strategija_195-0}

Skopje has 21 secondary schools; 5 of which serve as general high-school gymnasiums and 16 vocational schools.^[\[192\]](#cite_note-196)^ The city is also host to several higher education institutions, the most notable of which is [Ss. Cyril and Methodius University](/wiki/Ss._Cyril_and_Methodius_University_of_Skopje "Ss. Cyril and Methodius University of Skopje"), founded in 1949. The university has 23 departments, 10 research institutes and is attended by an average of 50,000 students.^[\[193\]](#cite_note-197)^ After the country's independence in 1991, several private universities were brought into existence. The largest private universities in Skopje are [European University Skopje](/wiki/European_University_Skopje "European University Skopje") with 7 departments^[\[194\]](#cite_note-198)^ and [FON University](/wiki/FON_University "FON University") with 9 departments respectively.^[\[195\]](#cite_note-199)^{#cite_ref-199}  

Media {#Media}
--------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Skopje&action=edit&section=35 "Edit section: Media")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7e/MRT_Center_3.jpg/200px-MRT_Center_3.jpg)](/wiki/File:MRT_Center_3.jpg) The [Macedonian Radio-Television headquarters](/wiki/MRT_Center "MRT Center")

Skopje is the largest media centre in North Macedonia. Of the 818 newspapers surveyed in 2000 by the Ministry of Information, over 600 had their headquarters in Skopje. The daily *[Dnevnik](/wiki/Dnevnik_(Skopje) "Dnevnik (Skopje)")*, founded in 1996, with 60 000 runs per day is the most printed in the country. Also based in Skopje, [Večer](/wiki/Ve%C4%8Der_(Macedonia) "Večer (Macedonia)") is pulled 50,000 copies and the state owns one-third of its capital, as well as [Nova Makedonija](/wiki/Nova_Makedonija "Nova Makedonija"), reprinted 20,000 copies. Other major newspapers in Skopje, totally private, are Utrinski Vesnik (30,000 copies), Vest (25,000 copies), and [Vreme](/wiki/Vreme_(newspaper) "Vreme (newspaper)") (15,000 copies). Magazines Fokus (12,000 copies), Start (10,000 copies), and Denes (7,500 copies) also have their headquarters in Skopje.^[\[196\]](#cite_note-media-200)^^[\[197\]](#cite_note-201)^{#cite_ref-201}

The city is home of the studios of [Macedonian Radio-Television](/wiki/Macedonian_Radio_Television "Macedonian Radio Television") (MRT), the country's public radio and television. Founded in 1966, it operates with three national broadcast channels, twenty-four hours a day. The most popular private television stations are [Sitel](/wiki/Sitel_(TV_channel) "Sitel (TV channel)"), [Kanal 5](/wiki/Kanal_5_(Macedonia) "Kanal 5 (Macedonia)"), Telma, Alfa TV, and AlsatM.^[\[198\]](#cite_note-202)^ MRT also operates radio stations with national coverage, the private station Skopje's Kanal 77 is the only one to have such a span. Radio [Antenna 5](/wiki/Antenna_5_FM "Antenna 5 FM") and Metropolis are two other major private stations that have their headquarters in Skopje.^[\[199\]](#cite_note-203)^{#cite_ref-203}

Also, the city boasts big news agencies in the country, both public, such as the [Media Information Agency](/wiki/Media_Information_Agency "Media Information Agency"), and private, such as the [Makfax](/wiki/Makfax "Makfax").^[\[196\]](#cite_note-media-200)^{#cite_ref-media_200-1}  

Sports {#Sports}
----------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Skopje&action=edit&section=36 "Edit section: Sports")\]  
Main article: [Sports in Skopje](/wiki/Sports_in_Skopje "Sports in Skopje")

As the capital and largest city of North Macedonia, Skopje has many major sporting facilities. The city has three large swimming pools, two of which feature Olympic pools. These pools are particularly relevant to coaching water polo teams. Skopje also boasts many football stadiums, like Ilinden in Čair and Železarnica, which can accommodate between 4,000 and 4,500 spectators. The basketball court Kale can accommodate 2,200 people and the court of Jane Sandanski has a 6,000 seat capacity.^[\[200\]](#cite_note-204)^{#cite_ref-204}
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/47/Skopje_X126.JPG/220px-Skopje_X126.JPG)](/wiki/File:Skopje_X126.JPG) The Toše Proeski Arena

The largest stadium remains [Toše Proeski Arena](/wiki/To%C5%A1e_Proeski_Arena "Toše Proeski Arena"). The stadium, built in 1947 and named until 2008, City Stadium Skopje^[\[201\]](#cite_note-205)^ experienced a total renovation, begun in 2009 to meet the standards of FIFA. Fully renovated the stadium contains 33,460 seats,^[\[202\]](#cite_note-206)^ and a health spa and fitness area. The [Boris Trajkovski Sports Center](/wiki/Boris_Trajkovski_Sports_Center "Boris Trajkovski Sports Center") is the largest sports complex in the country with 6,250 seats. It was opened in 2008 and named after former president [Boris Trajkovski](/wiki/Boris_Trajkovski "Boris Trajkovski"), who died in 2004. It includes rooms dedicated to handball, basketball, and volleyball, a bowling alley, a fitness area, and an ice hockey court. Its main hall, which regularly hosts concerts, holds around 10,000 people.^[\[203\]](#cite_note-207)^{#cite_ref-207}

[FK Vardar](/wiki/FK_Vardar "FK Vardar") and [FK Rabotnički](/wiki/FK_Rabotni%C4%8Dki "FK Rabotnički") are the two most popular football teams in the city. Vardar plays in the [second division](/wiki/Macedonian_Second_Football_League "Macedonian Second Football League"), whilst Rabotnicki plays in the [first division](/wiki/Macedonian_First_Football_League "Macedonian First Football League"). Their games are held at Toše Proeski Arena, like those of the national team. The city is also home to many smaller football clubs, such as: [FK Makedonija Ǵorče Petrov](/wiki/FK_Makedonija_%C7%B4or%C4%8De_Petrov "FK Makedonija Ǵorče Petrov"), [FK Gorno Lisiče](/wiki/FK_Gorno_Lisi%C4%8De "FK Gorno Lisiče"), [FK Lokomotiva Skopje](/wiki/FK_Lokomotiva_Skopje "FK Lokomotiva Skopje"), [FK Metalurg Skopje](/wiki/FK_Metalurg_Skopje "FK Metalurg Skopje"), [FK Madžari Solidarnost](/wiki/FK_Mad%C5%BEari_Solidarnost "FK Madžari Solidarnost") and [FK Skopje](/wiki/FK_Skopje "FK Skopje"), who play in first, second or third national league. Another popular sport in North Macedonia is basketball, represented in particular by the teams [MZT Skopje](/wiki/KK_MZT_Skopje "KK MZT Skopje") and [Rabotnički](/wiki/KK_Rabotni%C4%8Dki "KK Rabotnički"). Handball is illustrated by [RK Vardar](/wiki/RK_Vardar "RK Vardar") PRO and [RK Metalurg Skopje](/wiki/RK_Metalurg_Skopje "RK Metalurg Skopje"), also the women's team [ŽRK Metalurg](/wiki/%C5%BDRK_Metalurg "ŽRK Metalurg") and [ŽRK Vardar](/wiki/%C5%BDRK_Vardar "ŽRK Vardar"). The city co-hosted the [2008 European Women's Handball Championship](/wiki/2008_European_Women%27s_Handball_Championship "2008 European Women's Handball Championship") together with [Ohrid](/wiki/Ohrid "Ohrid"),^[\[204\]](#cite_note-208)^ and hosted the [2017 UEFA Super Cup](/wiki/2017_UEFA_Super_Cup "2017 UEFA Super Cup"), the match between the two giants of the European football [Real Madrid](/wiki/Real_Madrid "Real Madrid") and [Manchester United](/wiki/Manchester_United "Manchester United"){#cite_ref-208}  

Transport {#Transport}
----------------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Skopje&action=edit&section=37 "Edit section: Transport")\]  

### Main connections {#Main_connections}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Skopje&action=edit&section=38 "Edit section: Main connections")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/19/E65_Skopje_Northern_Bypass_1.jpg/220px-E65_Skopje_Northern_Bypass_1.jpg)](/wiki/File:E65_Skopje_Northern_Bypass_1.jpg) Skopje bypass

Skopje is near three other capital cities, [Pristina](/wiki/Pristina "Pristina") (87 km (54 mi) away), [Tirana](/wiki/Tirana "Tirana") (291 km) and [Sofia](/wiki/Sofia "Sofia") (245 km). [Thessaloniki](/wiki/Thessaloniki "Thessaloniki") is 233 km (145 mi) south and [Belgrade](/wiki/Belgrade "Belgrade") is 433 km (269 mi) north.^[\[205\]](#cite_note-rimed-209)^ Skopje is also at the crossroad of two [Pan-European corridors](/wiki/Pan-European_corridors "Pan-European corridors"): [Corridor X](/wiki/Pan-European_Corridor_X "Pan-European Corridor X"), which runs between [Austria](/wiki/Austria "Austria") and [Greece](/wiki/Greece "Greece"), and [Corridor VIII](/wiki/Pan-European_Corridor_VIII "Pan-European Corridor VIII"), which runs from the [Adriatic](/wiki/Adriatic_Sea "Adriatic Sea") in Albania to the [Black Sea](/wiki/Black_Sea "Black Sea") in Bulgaria. Corridor X links Skopje to Thessaloniki, Belgrade, and Western Europe, whilst Corridor VIII links it with Tirana and Sofia.{#cite_ref-rimed_209-0}

Corridor X locally corresponds to the [M-1 motorway](/w/index.php?title=M-1_motorway_(North_Macedonia)&action=edit&redlink=1 "M-1 motorway (North Macedonia) (page does not exist)") ([E75](/wiki/European_route_E75 "European route E75")), which is the longest highway in North Macedonia. It also corresponds to the [Tabanovce](/wiki/Tabanovce "Tabanovce")-[Gevgelija](/wiki/Gevgelija "Gevgelija") railway. Corridor VIII, less developed, corresponds to the M-4 motorway and the [Kičevo](/wiki/Ki%C4%8Devo "Kičevo")-Beljakovce railway. Skopje is not quite on the Corridor X and the M-1 does not pass on the city territory. Thus the junction between the M-1 and M-4 is some 20 km (12 mi) east, close to the airport. Although Skopje is geographically close to other major cities, movement of people and goods is not optimised, especially with [Albania](/wiki/Albania "Albania"). This is mainly due to poor infrastructure. As a result, 61.8% of Skopjans have never been to [Tirana](/wiki/Tirana "Tirana"), whilst only 6.7% have never been to [Thessaloniki](/wiki/Thessaloniki "Thessaloniki") and 0% to [Sofia](/wiki/Sofia "Sofia"). Furthermore, 26% of Thessalonians, 33% of Sofians and 37% of Tiranans have never been to Skopje.^[\[205\]](#cite_note-rimed-209)^{#cite_ref-rimed_209-1}

The first highways were built during the Yugoslav period, when Skopje was linked through the [Brotherhood and Unity Highway](/wiki/Brotherhood_and_Unity_Highway "Brotherhood and Unity Highway") to, what was then, the Yugoslav capital [Belgrade](/wiki/Belgrade "Belgrade") to the North, and the Greek border to the South.  

### Rail and coach stations {#Rail_and_coach_stations}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Skopje&action=edit&section=39 "Edit section: Rail and coach stations")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/00/Skopje_Train_Station_from_Mount_Vodno.JPG/220px-Skopje_Train_Station_from_Mount_Vodno.JPG)](/wiki/File:Skopje_Train_Station_from_Mount_Vodno.JPG) [Main railway station](/wiki/Transportation_Center_Skopje "Transportation Center Skopje") as seen from Mount [Vodno](/wiki/Vodno "Vodno")

The main railway station in Skopje is serviced by the [Belgrade](/wiki/Belgrade "Belgrade")-[Thessaloniki](/wiki/Thessaloniki "Thessaloniki") and Skopje-[Pristina](/wiki/Pristina "Pristina") international lines.^[\[206\]](#cite_note-mz-210)^ After the completion of the [Corridor VIII](/wiki/Pan-European_Corridor_VIII "Pan-European Corridor VIII") railway project, currently scheduled for 2030, the city will also be linked to [Tirana](/wiki/Tirana "Tirana") and [Sofia](/wiki/Sofia "Sofia").^[\[207\]](#cite_note-211)^^[\[208\]](#cite_note-212)^^[\[209\]](#cite_note-213)^ Daily trains also link Skopje with other towns of North Macedonia, such as [Kumanovo](/wiki/Kumanovo "Kumanovo"), [Kičevo](/wiki/Ki%C4%8Devo "Kičevo"), [Štip](/wiki/%C5%A0tip "Štip"), [Bitola](/wiki/Bitola "Bitola") or [Veles](/wiki/Veles_(city) "Veles (city)").^[\[206\]](#cite_note-mz-210)^{#cite_ref-mz_210-1}

Skopje has several minor railway stations but the city does not have its own railway network and they are only serviced by intercity or international lines. On the railway linking the [main station](/wiki/Transportation_Center_Skopje "Transportation Center Skopje") to Belgrade and Thessaloniki are Dračevo and Dolno Lisiče stations, and on the railway to Kičevo are Skopje-North, Ǵorče Petrov and Saraj stations. Several other stations are freight-only.^[\[210\]](#cite_note-stations-214)^{#cite_ref-stations_214-0}

Skopje coach station opened in 2005 and is built right under the main railway station. It can host 450 coaches in a day.^[\[211\]](#cite_note-215)^ Coach connections reach more destinations than train connections, connecting Skopje to many domestic and foreign destinations including [Istanbul](/wiki/Istanbul "Istanbul"), [Sofia](/wiki/Sofia "Sofia"), Prague, Hamburg and [Stockholm](/wiki/Stockholm "Stockholm").^[\[212\]](#cite_note-216)^{#cite_ref-216}  

### Public transport {#Public_transport}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Skopje&action=edit&section=40 "Edit section: Public transport")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7b/Yutong_City_Master_%28SK_9734-AC%29_JSP_%281%29.jpg/220px-Yutong_City_Master_%28SK_9734-AC%29_JSP_%281%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Yutong_City_Master_(SK_9734-AC)_JSP_(1).jpg) A red Yutong City Master double-decker bus in Skopje

Skopje has a bus network managed by the city and operated by three companies. The oldest and largest is JSP Skopje, a public company founded in 1948. JSP lost its monopoly on public transport in 1990 and two new companies, Sloboda Prevoz and Mak Ekspres, obtained several lines. However, most of the network is still in the hands of JSP which operates 67 lines out of 80. Only 24 lines are urban, the others serving localities around the city.^[\[213\]](#cite_note-transpower-217)^ Many of the JSP vehicles are red [Yutong City Master](/wiki/Yutong_City_Master "Yutong City Master") double-decker buses built by Chinese bus manufacturer [Yutong](/wiki/Yutong "Yutong") and designed to resemble the classic British [AEC Routemaster](/wiki/AEC_Routemaster "AEC Routemaster").^[\[214\]](#cite_note-218)^{#cite_ref-218}

A tram network has long been planned in Skopje and the idea was first proposed in the 1980s. The project became real in 2006 when the mayor Trifun Kostovski asked for feasibility studies. His successor Koce Trajanovski launched a call for tenders in 2010 and the first line is scheduled for 2019.^[\[215\]](#cite_note-219)^{#cite_ref-219}

A new network for small buses started to operate in June 2014, not to replace but to decrease the number of big buses in the city centre.  

### Airport {#Airport}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Skopje&action=edit&section=41 "Edit section: Airport")\]

The airport was built in 1928. The first commercial flights in Skopje were introduced in 1929 when the Yugoslav carrier [Aeroput](/wiki/Aeroput "Aeroput") introduced a route linking the city with the capital, [Belgrade](/wiki/Belgrade "Belgrade").^[\[216\]](#cite_note-aeroput-220)^ A year later the route was extended to [Thessaloniki](/wiki/Thessaloniki "Thessaloniki") in Greece, and further extended to Greek capital [Athens](/wiki/Athens "Athens") in 1933.^[\[216\]](#cite_note-aeroput-220)^ In 1935 Aeroput linked Skopje with [Bitola](/wiki/Bitola "Bitola") and [Niš](/wiki/Ni%C5%A1 "Niš"), and also operated a longer international route linking [Vienna](/wiki/Vienna "Vienna") and [Thessaloniki](/wiki/Thessaloniki "Thessaloniki") through [Zagreb](/wiki/Zagreb "Zagreb"), Belgrade and Skopje.^[\[216\]](#cite_note-aeroput-220)^ After the Second World War, Aeroput was replaced by [JAT Yugoslav Airlines](/wiki/JAT_Airways "JAT Airways"), which linked Skopje to a number of domestic and international destinations until the dissolution of Yugoslavia in the early 1990s.{#cite_ref-aeroput_220-2}

[Skopje International Airport](/wiki/Skopje_International_Airport "Skopje International Airport") is in [Petrovec](/wiki/Petrovec,_North_Macedonia "Petrovec, North Macedonia"), 20 km (12 mi) east of the city. Since 2008, it has been managed by the Turkish [TAV Airports Holding](/wiki/TAV_Airports_Holding "TAV Airports Holding") and it can accommodate up to four million passengers per year.^[\[217\]](#cite_note-tav-221)^ The annual traffic has constantly risen since 2008, reaching one million passengers in 2014.^[\[218\]](#cite_note-222)^{#cite_ref-222}

Skopje's airport has connections to several European cities, including [Athens](/wiki/Athens "Athens"), Vienna, [Bratislava](/wiki/Bratislava "Bratislava"), [Zürich](/wiki/Z%C3%BCrich "Zürich"), Brussels, [Oslo](/wiki/Oslo "Oslo"), [Istanbul](/wiki/Istanbul "Istanbul"), London and [Rome](/wiki/Rome "Rome"). It also maintains a direct connection with [Dubai](/wiki/Dubai "Dubai") and [Doha, Qatar](/wiki/Doha,_Qatar "Doha, Qatar").  

Culture {#Culture}
------------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Skopje&action=edit&section=42 "Edit section: Culture")\]  

### Cultural institutions {#Cultural_institutions}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Skopje&action=edit&section=43 "Edit section: Cultural institutions")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/00/Macedonian_Opera_and_Ballet_3.jpg/220px-Macedonian_Opera_and_Ballet_3.jpg)](/wiki/File:Macedonian_Opera_and_Ballet_3.jpg) Macedonian Opera and Ballet

Skopje is home to the largest cultural institutions of the country, such as the [National and University Library "St. Kliment of Ohrid"](/wiki/National_and_University_Library_%22St._Kliment_of_Ohrid%22 "National and University Library \"St. Kliment of Ohrid\""), the [Macedonian Academy of Sciences and Arts](/wiki/Macedonian_Academy_of_Sciences_and_Arts "Macedonian Academy of Sciences and Arts"), the National Theatre, the National Philharmonic Orchestra and the Macedonian Opera and Ballet. Amongst the local institutions are the Brothers Miladinov Library which has more than a million documents, the Cultural Information Centre which manages festivals, exhibitions and concerts, and the House of Culture Kočo Racin which is dedicated to [contemporary art](/wiki/Contemporary_art "Contemporary art") and young talents.^[\[219\]](#cite_note-223)^{#cite_ref-223}

Skopje has also several foreign cultural centres, such as a [Goethe-Institut](/wiki/Goethe-Institut "Goethe-Institut"),^[\[220\]](#cite_note-224)^ a [British Council](/wiki/British_Council "British Council"),^[\[221\]](#cite_note-225)^ an [Alliance française](/wiki/Alliance_fran%C3%A7aise "Alliance française"),^[\[222\]](#cite_note-226)^ an [American Corner](/wiki/American_Corner "American Corner").^[\[223\]](#cite_note-227)^{#cite_ref-227}

The city has several theatres and concert halls. The Univerzalna Sala, seating 1,570, was built in 1966 and is used for concerts, fashion shows, and congresses. The Metropolis Arena, designed for large concerts, has 3,546 seats. Other large halls include the Macedonian Opera and Ballet (800 seats), the National Theatre (724), and the Drama Theatre (333).^[\[224\]](#cite_note-228)^ Other smaller venues exist, such as the Albanian Theatre and the Youth Theatre. A Turkish Theatre and a Philharmonic hall are under construction.^[\[225\]](#cite_note-229)^^[\[226\]](#cite_note-230)^{#cite_ref-230}  

### Museums {#Museums}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Skopje&action=edit&section=44 "Edit section: Museums")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/13/Skopje_-_Museum_of_the_Macedonian_Struggle.jpg/220px-Skopje_-_Museum_of_the_Macedonian_Struggle.jpg)](/wiki/File:Skopje_-_Museum_of_the_Macedonian_Struggle.jpg) [Museum of the Macedonian Struggle](/wiki/Museum_of_the_Macedonian_Struggle_(Skopje) "Museum of the Macedonian Struggle (Skopje)")

The largest museum in Skopje is the [Museum of the Republic of North Macedonia](/wiki/Museum_of_the_Republic_of_North_Macedonia "Museum of the Republic of North Macedonia") which details the history of the country. Its [icons](/wiki/Icon "Icon") and lapidary collections are particularly rich.^[\[227\]](#cite_note-231)^ The Macedonian Archeological Museum, opened in 2014, keeps some of the best archeological finds in North Macedonia, dating from [Prehistory](/wiki/Prehistory "Prehistory") to the Ottoman period. The [National Gallery of Macedonia](/wiki/National_Gallery_of_Macedonia "National Gallery of Macedonia") exhibits paintings dating from the 14th to the 20th century in two former [hammams](/wiki/Hammam "Hammam") of the [Old Bazaar](/wiki/Old_Bazaar,_Skopje "Old Bazaar, Skopje"). The [Contemporary Art Museum](/wiki/Contemporary_Art_Museum_(North_Macedonia) "Contemporary Art Museum (North Macedonia)") was built after the 1963 earthquake thanks to international assistance. Its collections include Macedonian and foreign art, with works by [Fernand Léger](/wiki/Fernand_L%C3%A9ger "Fernand Léger"), [André Masson](/wiki/Andr%C3%A9_Masson "André Masson"), [Pablo Picasso](/wiki/Pablo_Picasso "Pablo Picasso"), [Hans Hartung](/wiki/Hans_Hartung "Hans Hartung"), [Victor Vasarely](/wiki/Victor_Vasarely "Victor Vasarely"), [Alexander Calder](/wiki/Alexander_Calder "Alexander Calder"), [Pierre Soulages](/wiki/Pierre_Soulages "Pierre Soulages"), [Alberto Burri](/wiki/Alberto_Burri "Alberto Burri") and [Christo](/wiki/Christo "Christo").^[\[228\]](#cite_note-232)^{#cite_ref-232}

The [Skopje City Museum](/wiki/Skopje_City_Museum "Skopje City Museum") is inside the remains of the old railway station, destroyed by the 1963 earthquake. It is dedicated to local history and it has four departments: archeology, [ethnology](/wiki/Ethnology "Ethnology"), history, and art history.^[\[229\]](#cite_note-233)^ The [Memorial House of Mother Teresa](/wiki/Memorial_House_of_Mother_Teresa "Memorial House of Mother Teresa") was built in 2009 on the original site of the church in which the nun had been baptised.^[\[230\]](#cite_note-234)^ The [Museum of the Macedonian Struggle](/wiki/Museum_of_the_Macedonian_Struggle_(Skopje) "Museum of the Macedonian Struggle (Skopje)") is dedicated to the modern national history and the struggle of Macedonians for their independence. Nearby is the [Holocaust Memorial Center for the Jews of Macedonia](/wiki/Holocaust_Memorial_Center_for_the_Jews_of_Macedonia "Holocaust Memorial Center for the Jews of Macedonia"). The Macedonian Museum of Natural History showcases some 4,000 items^[\[231\]](#cite_note-235)^ whilst the 12-ha [Skopje Zoo](/wiki/Skopje_Zoo "Skopje Zoo") is home to 300 animals.^[\[232\]](#cite_note-236)^{#cite_ref-236}  

### Architecture {#Architecture}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Skopje&action=edit&section=45 "Edit section: Architecture")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f7/Skupi_%28Colonia_Flavia_Scupinorum%29_-_by_Pudelek_1.JPG/220px-Skupi_%28Colonia_Flavia_Scupinorum%29_-_by_Pudelek_1.JPG)](/wiki/File:Skupi_(Colonia_Flavia_Scupinorum)_-_by_Pudelek_1.JPG) Ruins of Roman [Scupi](/wiki/Scupi "Scupi")

Although Skopje has been destroyed many times throughout its history, it still has many historical landmarks which reflect the successive occupations of the city. Skopje has one of the biggest Ottoman urban complexes in Europe, with many Ottoman monuments still serving their original purpose. It was also a ground for [modernist](/wiki/Modernist_architecture "Modernist architecture") experiments in the 20th century, following the 1963 earthquake. At the beginning of the 21st century, it is again the subject of massive building campaigns, thanks to the "[Skopje 2014](/wiki/Skopje_2014 "Skopje 2014")" project. Skopje is thus an environment where old, new, progressist, reactionary, eastern and western perspectives coexist.^[\[134\]](#cite_note-colophon-138)^{#cite_ref-colophon_138-1}
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/22/Skopje_Aqueduct_9.jpg/220px-Skopje_Aqueduct_9.jpg)](/wiki/File:Skopje_Aqueduct_9.jpg) Skopje Aqueduct

Skopje has some remains of Prehistorical architecture which can be seen on the [Tumba Madžari](/wiki/Tumba_Mad%C5%BEari "Tumba Madžari") Neolithic site.^[\[233\]](#cite_note-237)^ On the other side of the city lie the remains of the ancient [Scupi](/wiki/Scupi "Scupi"), with ruins of a theatre, thermae and a basilica.^[\[70\]](#cite_note-archeology-73)^ The [Skopje Aqueduct](/wiki/Skopje_Aqueduct "Skopje Aqueduct"), between Scupi and the city centre, is rather mysterious because its date of construction is unknown. It seems to have been built by the Byzantines or the Turks, but it was already out of use in the 16th century.^[\[234\]](#cite_note-238)^ It consists of 50 arches, worked in cloisonné masonry.^[\[235\]](#cite_note-strategic-239)^{#cite_ref-strategic_239-0}
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/05/Manastir_sveti_Pantelejmon_vo_selo_Nerezi.jpg/220px-Manastir_sveti_Pantelejmon_vo_selo_Nerezi.jpg)](/wiki/File:Manastir_sveti_Pantelejmon_vo_selo_Nerezi.jpg) Church of Saint Panteleimon

[Skopje Fortress](/wiki/Skopje_Fortress "Skopje Fortress") was rebuilt several times before it was destroyed by the 1963 earthquake. Since then, it has been restored to its medieval appearance. It is the only medieval monument in Skopje, but several churches around the city illustrate the [Vardar architectural school](/wiki/Serbo-Byzantine_architecture "Serbo-Byzantine architecture") which flourished around 1300. Amongst these churches are the ones around [Matka Canyon](/wiki/Matka_Canyon "Matka Canyon") (St Nicholas, St Andrew and Matka churches). The [church of Saint Panteleimon](/wiki/Church_of_Saint_Panteleimon,_Gorno_Nerezi "Church of Saint Panteleimon, Gorno Nerezi") in [Gorno Nerezi](/wiki/Gorno_Nerezi "Gorno Nerezi") dates from the 12th century. Its expressive frescoes anticipate the [Italian primitives](/wiki/Italian_primitives "Italian primitives").^[\[236\]](#cite_note-240)^{#cite_ref-240}
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ec/Isak_Bey_Turbe_Aladja_Mosque_Skopje.JPG/220px-Isak_Bey_Turbe_Aladja_Mosque_Skopje.JPG)](/wiki/File:Isak_Bey_Turbe_Aladja_Mosque_Skopje.JPG) Aladža Mosque and its türbe

Examples of [Ottoman architecture](/wiki/Ottoman_architecture "Ottoman architecture") are in the [Old Bazaar](/wiki/Old_Bazaar,_Skopje "Old Bazaar, Skopje"). Mosques in Skopje are usually simple in design, with a square base and a single [dome](/wiki/Dome "Dome") and [minaret](/wiki/Minaret "Minaret"). Their entrance is usually emphasised by a portico, as on [Mustafa Pasha Mosque](/wiki/Mustafa_Pasha_Mosque "Mustafa Pasha Mosque"), dating from the 15th century. Some mosques show some originality in their appearance: [Sultan Murad](/wiki/Sultan_Murad_Mosque "Sultan Murad Mosque") and Yahya Pasha mosques have lost their dome and have a pyramidal roof, whilst Isa Bey mosque has a rectangular base, two domes and two side wings. The Aladža Mosque was originally covered with blue faience, but it disappeared in the 1689 Great Fire. However, some tiles are still visible on the adjoining [türbe](/wiki/T%C3%BCrbe "Türbe"). Other Ottoman public monuments include the 16th-century clock tower, a [bedesten](/wiki/Bedesten "Bedesten"), three [caravanserais](/wiki/Caravanserai "Caravanserai"), two [hammams](/wiki/Hammam "Hammam") and the [Stone Bridge](/wiki/Stone_Bridge_(Skopje) "Stone Bridge (Skopje)"), first mentioned in 1469.^[\[99\]](#cite_note-ottoman-103)^^[\[237\]](#cite_note-oldskopje-241)^{#cite_ref-oldskopje_241-0}

The oldest churches in the city centre, the [Ascension](/wiki/Church_of_the_Ascension_of_Jesus,_Skopje "Church of the Ascension of Jesus, Skopje") and St Dimitri churches, were built in the 18th century, after the 1689 Great Fire. They were both renovated in the 19th century. The Church of the Ascension is particularly small it is half-buried in order not to overlook neighbouring mosques.^[\[238\]](#cite_note-242)^ In the 19th century, several new churches were built, including the Church of the Nativity of the Virgin Mary, which is a large three-nave building designed by [Andrey Damyanov](/wiki/Andrey_Damyanov "Andrey Damyanov").^[\[239\]](#cite_note-243)^{#cite_ref-243}
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/47/Po%C5%A1ta_vo_Skopje%2C_Macedonia.jpg/220px-Po%C5%A1ta_vo_Skopje%2C_Macedonia.jpg)](/wiki/File:Po%C5%A1ta_vo_Skopje,_Macedonia.jpg) Main post office and the Communication Centre

After 1912, when Skopje was annexed by Serbia, the city was drastically westernised. Wealthy Serbs built mansions and town houses such as the 1926 [Ristiḱ Palace](/wiki/Risti%E1%B8%B1_Palace "Ristiḱ Palace"). The architecture of that time is very similar to the one of Central Europe, but some buildings are more creative, such as the [Neo-Moorish](/wiki/Moorish_Revival_architecture "Moorish Revival architecture") Arab House and the [Neo-Byzantine](/wiki/Byzantine_Revival_architecture "Byzantine Revival architecture") train station, both built in 1938.^[\[134\]](#cite_note-colophon-138)^ [Modernism](/wiki/Modernist_architecture "Modernist architecture") appeared as early as 1933 with the former Ethnographic Museum (today the City Gallery), designed by [Milan Zloković](/wiki/Milan_Zlokovi%C4%87 "Milan Zloković").^[\[134\]](#cite_note-colophon-138)^ However, modernist architecture only fully developed in Skopje after the 1963 earthquake. The reconstruction of the city centre was partially planned by Japanese [Kenzo Tange](/wiki/Kenzo_Tange "Kenzo Tange") who designed the new train station.^[\[134\]](#cite_note-colophon-138)^ Macedonian architects also took part in the reconstruction: [Georgi Konstantinovski](/wiki/Georgi_Konstantinovski "Georgi Konstantinovski") designed the City Archives building in 1968 and the Hall of residence Goce Delčev in 1975, whilst [Janko Konstantinov](/wiki/Janko_Konstantinov "Janko Konstantinov") designed the Telecommunication Centre and the main post office (1974--1989). [Slavko Brezovski](/wiki/Slavko_Brezovski "Slavko Brezovski") designed the [Church of St. Clement of Ohrid](/wiki/Church_of_St._Clement_of_Ohrid "Church of St. Clement of Ohrid").^[\[240\]](#cite_note-244)^ These two buildings are noted for their originality although they are directly inspired by [brutalism](/wiki/Brutalist_architecture "Brutalist architecture").^[\[134\]](#cite_note-colophon-138)^{#cite_ref-colophon_138-5}

The reconstruction turned Skopje into a proper modernist city, with large blocks of flats, austere concrete buildings and scattered green spaces. The city centre was considered as a grey and unattractive place when local authorities unveiled the "[Skopje 2014](/wiki/Skopje_2014 "Skopje 2014")" project in 2010.^[\[241\]](#cite_note-245)^^[\[242\]](#cite_note-246)^ It made plans to erect a large number of statues, fountains, bridges, and museums at a cost of about €500 million.^[\[243\]](#cite_note-247)^{#cite_ref-247}

The project has generated controversy: critics have described the new landmark buildings as signs of reactionary [historicist](/wiki/Historicism_(art) "Historicism (art)") aesthetics.^[\[244\]](#cite_note-Skopje2014-248)^ Also, the government has been criticised for its cost and the original lack of representation of national minorities in the coverage of its set of statues and memorials.^[\[244\]](#cite_note-Skopje2014-248)^ However, representations of minorities have since been included amongst the monuments. The scheme is accused of turning Skopje to a [theme park](/wiki/Theme_park "Theme park"),^[\[245\]](#cite_note-249)^ which is viewed as nationalistic [kitsch](/wiki/Kitsch "Kitsch"),^[\[246\]](#cite_note-250)^ and has made Skopje an example to see how national identities are constructed and how this construction is mirrored in the urban space.^[\[247\]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHeroldLangerLechler2010[httpsbooksgooglecombooksidsgfc1TosZGYCdqantiquizationpgPA43_43]-251)^{#cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHeroldLangerLechler2010[httpsbooksgooglecombooksidsgfc1TosZGYCdqantiquizationpgPA43_43]_251-0}

### Festivals {#Festivals}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Skopje&action=edit&section=46 "Edit section: Festivals")\]

The [Skopje Jazz Festival](/wiki/Skopje_Jazz_Festival "Skopje Jazz Festival") has been held annually in October since 1981. It is part of the European Jazz Network and the European Forum of World Wide Festivals. The artists' profiles include fusion, [acid jazz](/wiki/Acid_jazz "Acid jazz"), [Latin jazz](/wiki/Latin_jazz "Latin jazz"), [smooth jazz](/wiki/Smooth_jazz "Smooth jazz"), and [avant-garde jazz](/wiki/Avant-garde_jazz "Avant-garde jazz"). [Ray Charles](/wiki/Ray_Charles "Ray Charles"), [Tito Puente](/wiki/Tito_Puente "Tito Puente"), [Gotan Project](/wiki/Gotan_Project "Gotan Project"), [Al Di Meola](/wiki/Al_Di_Meola "Al Di Meola"), [Youssou N'Dour](/wiki/Youssou_N%27Dour "Youssou N'Dour"), amongst others, have performed at the festival. Another music festival in Skopje is the Blues and Soul Festival. It is a relatively new event in the Macedonian cultural scene that occurs every summer in early July.^[\[248\]](#cite_note-252)^ Past guests include [Larry Coryell](/wiki/Larry_Coryell "Larry Coryell"), [Mick Taylor](/wiki/Mick_Taylor "Mick Taylor") \& the All-Stars Blues Band, [Candy Dulfer](/wiki/Candy_Dulfer "Candy Dulfer") \& Funky Stuff, [João Bosco](/wiki/Jo%C3%A3o_Bosco "João Bosco"), [the Temptations](/wiki/The_Temptations "The Temptations"), [Tolo Marton](/w/index.php?title=Tolo_Marton&action=edit&redlink=1 "Tolo Marton (page does not exist)") Trio, [Blues Wire](/w/index.php?title=Blues_Wire&action=edit&redlink=1 "Blues Wire (page does not exist)"), and [Phil Guy](/wiki/Phil_Guy "Phil Guy").{#cite_ref-252}

The Skopje Cultural Summer Festival is a renowned cultural event that takes place in Skopje each year during the summer. The festival is a member of the [International Festivals and Events Association](/wiki/International_Festivals_and_Events_Association "International Festivals and Events Association") (IFEA) and it includes musical concerts, operas, ballets, plays, art and photograph exhibitions, movies, and multimedia projects that gather 2,000 participants from around the world each year including the [St Petersburg](/wiki/St_Petersburg "St Petersburg") Theatre, the Chamber Orchestra of the [Bolshoi Theatre](/wiki/Bolshoi_Theatre "Bolshoi Theatre"), [Irina Arkhipova](/wiki/Irina_Arkhipova "Irina Arkhipova"), [Viktor Tretiakov](/wiki/Viktor_Tretiakov "Viktor Tretiakov"), The Theatre of Shadows, [Michel Dalberto](/wiki/Michel_Dalberto "Michel Dalberto"), and [David Burgess](/wiki/Dave_Burgess_(musician) "Dave Burgess (musician)").

May Opera Evenings is a festival that has occurred annually in Skopje since 1972 and is dedicated to promoting opera amongst the general public. Over the years, it has evolved into a stage on which artists from some 50 countries have performed. There is one other major international theatre festival that takes place each year at the end of September, the Young Open Theater Festival (MOT), which was organised for the first time in May 1976 by the Youth Cultural Center -- Skopje.^[\[249\]](#cite_note-253)^ More than 700 theatrical performances have been presented at this festival so far, most of them being alternative, [experimental theatre](/wiki/Experimental_theatre "Experimental theatre") groups engaging young writers and actors. The MOT International Theatre Festival is also a member of the [International Network for Contemporary Performing Arts or IETM](/wiki/International_Network_for_Contemporary_Performing_Arts_(IETM) "International Network for Contemporary Performing Arts (IETM)").^[\[250\]](#cite_note-254)^ Within the framework of the MOT Festival, the Macedonian National Center of the International Theater Institute (ITI) was established, and at the 25th ITI World Congress in Munich in 1993, it became a regular member of this theatre association. The festival has an international character, always representing theatres from all over the world that present and enhance the exchange and circulation of young-fresh-experimental-avant-garde theatrical energy and experience between its participants on one side and the audience on the other.{#cite_ref-254}

The [Skopje Film Festival](/w/index.php?title=Skopje_Film_Festival&action=edit&redlink=1 "Skopje Film Festival (page does not exist)") is an annual event held in the city every March. Over 50 films are shown at this five-day festival, mostly from North Macedonia and Europe, but also including some non-commercial film productions from all over the world.  

### Nightlife {#Nightlife}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Skopje&action=edit&section=47 "Edit section: Nightlife")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4f/Skopije_at_night.jpg/220px-Skopije_at_night.jpg)](/wiki/File:Skopije_at_night.jpg) Panorama of Skopje at night

Skopje has a diverse nightlife. There is a large emphasis on casinos, many of which are associated with hotels. In 2010, the Colosseum club was named fifth on a list of the best clubs in [South-eastern Europe](/wiki/South-eastern_Europe "South-eastern Europe"). [Armin van Buuren](/wiki/Armin_van_Buuren "Armin van Buuren"), [Above and Beyond](/wiki/Above_and_Beyond_(band) "Above and Beyond (band)"), [The Shapeshifters](/wiki/Shapeshifters_(music_act) "Shapeshifters (music act)") are just some of the many musicians that have visited the club.^[\[251\]](#cite_note-255)^ Nighttime concerts in local, regional and global music are often held at the [Toše Proeski Arena](/wiki/To%C5%A1e_Proeski_Arena "Toše Proeski Arena") and [Boris Trajkovski Sports Center](/wiki/Boris_Trajkovski_Sports_Center "Boris Trajkovski Sports Center").^[\[252\]](#cite_note-Nightlife-256)^ For middle-aged people, places for having fun are also the *[kafeanas](/wiki/Kafana "Kafana")* where traditional [Macedonian food](/wiki/Cuisine_of_North_Macedonia "Cuisine of North Macedonia") is served and traditional [Macedonian music](/wiki/Music_of_North_Macedonia "Music of North Macedonia") (*[Starogradska muzika](/wiki/Starogradska_muzika "Starogradska muzika")* ) is played, but [music from all the Balkans](/wiki/Balkan_music "Balkan music"), particularly [Serbian folk music](/wiki/Music_of_Serbia "Music of Serbia") is also popular. Apart from the traditional Macedonian restaurants, there are restaurants featuring international cuisines.^[\[252\]](#cite_note-Nightlife-256)^ The [Old Bazaar](/wiki/Old_Bazaar,_Skopje "Old Bazaar, Skopje") was a popular nightlife destination in the past. The [national government](/wiki/Government_of_North_Macedonia "Government of North Macedonia") has created a project to revive nightlife in the Old Bazaar. The closing time in shops, cafés and restaurants was extended due to the high attendances recorded. In the bazaar's restaurants, along with the traditional Macedonian wine and food, dishes of the [Ottoman cuisine](/wiki/Ottoman_cuisine "Ottoman cuisine") are also served.^[\[253\]](#cite_note-257)^{#cite_ref-257}

The place-name *Shkup* is evidenced as *Scupi-* in ancient records, as for ex. in *Itineraria Romana* 1916 (of the III-IV centuries A.D.)77. ln the Balkan Slavic languages this place-name sounds with the initial /*Sko-* /: *Skopie* , whereas in Albanian the initial /*Shku-* / in *Shkup-i* is a direct reflection of the ancient /*Scu-* /, and this excludes a Slavic intermediation. 16. **[\^](#cite_ref-17)** [Popullsia shqiptare e Kosovës gjatë shek studime dhe dokumente. XV-XVI - Selami Pulaha 1984](https://www.google.com/books/edition/Popullsia_shqiptare_e_Kosov%C3%ABs_gjat%C3%AB_sh/AuwJAQAAIAAJ?hl=en&gbpv=0&bsq=popullsia%20shqiptare%20e%20kosoves) - 'Other ancient toponyms that belong to the Albanian territories in the former Yugoslavia have evolved in accordance to the historical phonetic rules of the Albanian language. Such cases are Naissus-Nish, Scupi-Shkup, Astibos-Shtip, Scardus-Shar, Ulpiana-Lipjan and many more. The explanation of why these ancient names have arrived to us in the form they did, is that these territories have been inhabited by Albanians continuously and not intermittingly. The presence of an Albanian speaking population has been preserved mostly in the names of the towns. This evidence demonstrates that the Albanian population could not have been made up of shepherds sheltered in the highlands or the mountains. Quite on the contrary, that population was urbanized and apparently with an advanced standard of living for its time. Among other factors, the ancient toponomastic data, such as the contemporary names of places used by Slavs, which are explainable only through the phonetic rules of the ancient Albanian language, has convinced scientists that these territories were inhabited by Albanians. Distinguished linguists such as Norbert Jokl, Gustav Weygand, and Petrovici, and even some Yugoslav scholars like Henrik Baric and others, have argued that it was precisely Dardania, defined as an enclave by the use of the ancient names such as Nish, Shkup, Shtip that was one of the centers of the formation of the Albanian people.'{#cite_note-17}

100. **[\^](#cite_ref-104)** Rexha, Iljaz (2011). ["Vendbanimet dhe popullsia albane gjatë mesjetës në hapësirën e Maqedonisë së sotme: Sipas burimeve sllave dhe osmane"](https://www.ceeol.com/search/article-detail?id=70066). *Gjurmime Albanologjike: Seria e Shkencave Historike* (41--42): 167--218Në defterin kadastral të vitit 1451-52 për Rumelinë, në Shkup ishte regjistruar lagjeja Gjin-ko --(Gjinaj), me emrin e familjes fisnike mesjetare albane, ku në dokumente sllave të shek.XIV, por edhe në defterët osmanë të shek.XV-XIV, permenden 5 vendbanime me emrin Gjinofc në rrthinat e Shtipt, të Kriva Pallankes, të Gostivarit, Tetovës dhe të Dibres si dhe 2 tjera me emrin Gjinofc janë regjitruar në hapësirën në mes Radomirit dhe të Qystendilit në Bullgari, vendbanime këto qe në mesjetë i themeluan vëllezritë e Gjinajve. Në lagjen e sipërpërmendur Gjinko, në radhë të parë ishte regjistruar kryefamiljari Gjin-ko, me profesion (këpuctarë), dhe Todori, i vëllai i tij (Gjinit), siç shihet themelues i kësaj lagje, ndersa më vonë, në këtë lagjë, në vitin 1467 ishte regjistruar djali i tij Marko, i biri i Gjinit, pastaj në mesin e banorëve të tjerë, ishin regjistruar edhe banorë me antroponimi simbiotike krishtere tradicionale arbane: Milesh-a, bostanxhi, Dimitri, i biri i Prençes, Dragati, i biri i Male-s (Malja), Nikolla, i biri i Naneçit (Nano), Jovan i vëllai i tij, Jako i biri i Dodanit (Doda), Stepan, i biri i Andreas, Paliq (Pali) i biri i Stepanit, Nikolla i biri i Drralla, Roza, e vejë.`{{`[cite journal](/wiki/Template:Cite_journal "Template:Cite journal")`}}`: CS1 maint: postscript ([link](/wiki/Category:CS1_maint:_postscript "Category:CS1 maint: postscript")){#cite_note-104}
{#cite_note-104}
101. **[\^](#cite_ref-105)** Rexha, Iljaz (2011). ["Vendbanimet dhe popullsia albane gjatë mesjetës në hapësirën e Maqedonisë së sotme: Sipas burimeve sllave dhe osmane"](https://www.ceeol.com/search/article-detail?id=70066). *Gjurmime Albanologjike: Seria e Shkencave Historike* (41--42): 167--218Si dëshmi tjetër për praninë e albanëve në territorrin e Maqedonisë së sotme ishin edhe spahinjtë vendas, me prejardhje albane e jo të ardhur nga Arbanoni politik mesjetar, që më parë kishin kaluar në fenë islame dhe ishin inkuadruar në sistemin e timarit të spahinjve osmanë. Sipas defterëve të shek. XV (1451/53 dhe 1467/68) ata i kishin timaret e veta në territorin e Maqedonisë dhe të Kosovës, kësaj radhe po i përmendim vetëm disa prej tyre: Hamza Arnauti,59 nga mëhalla Mentesheli e Shku-pit e kishte timarin e vet në fshatin Gumaleva. Hamza Arnauti, (tjetër) nga vendbanimi Niçevo (Nokova) e Shkupit kishte timarin e tij në fshatin Pa-garusha. Jusuf Arnauti, nga fshati Topçe Is'akli afër Draçevës së Shkupit. Shahin Arnauti59/a dizdar i kalasë së Shkupit i kishte timarin në tri fshatra të Shkupit... pranë individit me etno-nimin Arbanas ose Arnaut, apelativi sllav: doshlac prishlac, uselica, emigrant, që do thotë se kryefamiljarët shqiptarëme këtë etnonim si:Petro Arbanas, Dimitri Arbanas, Nikolla Arbanas, Bogdan Arbanas, Bogoslav Arbanas, Milosh Arbanas, Bozhidar Arnaut, Gjuro Arba-nas, Mihajl Arbanas, Todor Arnaut, Andreja Arnaut, Lzar Arnaut apo Jusuf Arnaut, ose Hamza Arnavut etj., nuk janë shënuar me cilë-sorin sllav doselic ose prishlec, çka dëshmon se ata ishin vendës në vendbanimet e tyre`{{`[cite journal](/wiki/Template:Cite_journal "Template:Cite journal")`}}`: CS1 maint: postscript ([link](/wiki/Category:CS1_maint:_postscript "Category:CS1 maint: postscript")){#cite_note-105}
{#cite_note-105}

103. **[\^](#cite_ref-107)** Rexha, Iljaz (2011). ["Vendbanimet dhe popullsia albane gjatë mesjetës në hapësirën e Maqedonisë së sotme: Sipas burimeve sllave dhe osmane"](https://www.ceeol.com/search/article-detail?id=70066). *Gjurmime Albanologjike: Seria e Shkencave Historike* (41--42): 167--218Në lagjenAhrijan Hasantë Shkupit të vitit 1451/53 ishte re-gjistruar në mesin e kryefamiljarëve myslimanë edhe kryefamiljari me partonimin e familjes fisnike albane Muzak, që kishte kaluar në islam, duke mos e përmendur emrin e tij të mëhershëm të krishterë dhe pa e theksuar pozitën shoqërore apo profesionin e tij.77 Në defterin tjetër të vitit 1467/68, tani në lagjen e krishterë me emrin Svetko Samarxhi tëShkupit, në mesin e 29 kryefamiljarëve me antroponimi krishtere sllave janë regjistruar: Nikolla, i biri Muzak-es, Todor, i biri Shendre-es (Shen Andre-it), Gjuro, i biri Marin-it, Jovan, i biri Suteç-it ( Suta). Nga këto të dhëna të këtyre dy defterëve shihet qartë, se këta dy kryefamiljarë me mbiemrin Muzaka, njëri i krishterë e tjetri mysliman ishin farefis dhe banorë të vjetër të Shkupit, ngase të parët e familjeve të tyre që nga mesjeta e hershme banonin në hapësirat e rajoneve të Nishit, Kosovës dhe të Maqedonisë sotme, pra para depërtimit osman në Ballkan`{{`[cite journal](/wiki/Template:Cite_journal "Template:Cite journal")`}}`: CS1 maint: postscript ([link](/wiki/Category:CS1_maint:_postscript "Category:CS1 maint: postscript")){#cite_note-107}
{#cite_note-107}
104. **[\^](#cite_ref-108)** Rexha, Iljaz (2011). ["Vendbanimet dhe popullsia albane gjatë mesjetës në hapësirën e Maqedonisë së sotme: Sipas burimeve sllave dhe osmane"](https://www.ceeol.com/search/article-detail?id=70066). *Gjurmime Albanologjike: Seria e Shkencave Historike* (41--42): 167--218Në vijim po japim edhe disa të dhëna për spahinjtë e krishterë me prejardhje albane, që i kishin timaret e veta së bashku me individë të tjerë, në simbiozë me antroponimi sllave në rrethinën e Shkupit, ku shihet se edhe këta ishin vendas, meqë në defterë, posaçërisht theksohet se këta individë ishin spahinj të vjetër, çka kuptohet se edhe para viteve 1467-68, në regjistrimet e mëhershme, që nuk janë ruajtur, i kanë pasur timaret e tyre. Timari i Mirashit të birit të Todorit, i Dobroslavit, i të birit të Jaroslavit, i Kojçinit i të birit të Gjonit ,..... (dhe 4 individë të tjerë ). Timari i Gjurës i biri i Todorit, Petko i vëllai i Ibrahimit, Gjoni i vëlla i Petkos (Ibrahimit), Gjura i biri i Petko ( Ibrahimit ) dhe Lazori i biri Petko ( Ibrahimit ).Timari Hamzajt i vëlla i Ibrahimit, Gjoni i vëlla i Hamzait të vëllait të Ibrahimit, Nikolla i vëlla i tij Gjonit, Pavli i biri i Mihos, Pejo i biri i Pavlit, Petko i biri i Gjonit i vëllai i Hamzait të vëllait të Ibrahimit...Kemi edhe shumë spahinj tjerë me prejardhje albane si: Ali dhe Hamza Kërçovali, nga Kër-çova, Shimerd Vardarli i Shkupit, Mahmud Manastirli, Ali Arnauti etj. shihet qartazi se këta posedues të timareve ishin nga trojet e sotme të Maqedonisë e jo të ardhur nga Shqipëria e Qendrore e sotme.`{{`[cite journal](/wiki/Template:Cite_journal "Template:Cite journal")`}}`: CS1 maint: postscript ([link](/wiki/Category:CS1_maint:_postscript "Category:CS1 maint: postscript")){#cite_note-108}
